It isn't a painful delusion, because you both know it isn't real. You feel at peace. You feel some of the danger of the last few days slip away, and gain a sort of clarity.
You kiss with that passion which can only come from desperation. You drink deep of each other, unsure if this will be your last chance to ever do so.
The two of you sit on a the edge of the dock together. You laugh and joke, you talk about which books you've been reading recently. Together, you pretend that nothing is ever going to change.
Unable to restrain yourself further, you grab Ludovico by the wrist and lead him behind a nearby building for one last embrace.
"I guess, this is goodbye."
However, his joy quickly fades, as he remembers what you're both here to do.
He pushes through the crowd to get to you. "Yvette! I'm so glad you came. You have no idea how much this means to me."
(You have gained a little favor with Ludovico)
You spot Ludovico walking down from a gangplank, and peering into the crowd. When he spots you, his face blossoms into an exuberant smile.

Finally, you make it to the docks. Instead of the normal bevy of merchant vessels, you only see barges taking on passengers, laden with their world possessions. The barges will take them via the river to a proper port city. Most people with the means to leave Paris, are leaving France altogether.
You've already lost a lot of time from having to double back and find new routes. It looks like new barricades are going up every day, and the streets simply don't feel safe anymore.
You hurry south through the city, trying to make sure that you make it to the docks in time.
"This isn't 'goodbye'. Just 'see you soon'."

You stop to think about this new information. Marcelle is a wealthy aristocrat, but her fortune appears to be younger than she claims. It seems like this knowledge could be useful, but you’ll have to dig deeper first.
“Ciao, madame.” Ludovico says before leaving.

“Honestly, it’s been a nice change of pace. Normally I just spend a lot of time listening to bishops and writing letters back to the Vatican. This has me out and about, enjoying Paris, and getting a feel for its people.”
“Haha! Sorry, I’ve always wanted to say something like that.”

“While I must go, remember that all of this is speculation. If you want to use any of this information against Marcelle, you’ll need indisputable proof of whatever lies or wrongdoing she’s engaged in, or it’ll simply be your word against hers. Still, I will pray for your success.”
You’re not sure if Ludovico helping you exact your revenge could really be classified as ‘the right thing’, but you’re not going to complain.

Ludovico leans in close and whispers in your ear, his voice barely audible. “Madame, Rome chose me as their eyes and ears in France. You didn’t think that they’d sent someone who’s never gotten their hands dirty, did you?”
“Think nothing of it madame, I’m just trying to do the right thing.”
“It feels like Marcelle is hiding something, and it has to do with her money.”

“Thirty years is a long time for most people, yes, but compared to most aristocratic families, that’s barely the blink of an eye. From the mindset of the clergy, it’s even less. There are churches in France that are over 1,000 years old. Why would her family pretend their fortune is older than it really is?”

“Strangely enough, the moment I actually started looking into Marcelle’s wealth and position, something didn’t feel right. She claims that her storied family fortune comes from a series of wise investments, so I started paying visits and offering blessings to some of her family’s known business partners. In that whole time, I couldn’t find evidence that any of her family’s investments were older than thirty years or so.”

“... is a very good point,” he admits with a defeated sigh. You can tell that he was quite enjoying this air of intrigue, but you’d rather have some quick results. Ludovico sits down next to you and composes himself.

“I know I’ve already said this before, but I still want to tell you that I’m sorry for everything that happened to you. From what I know, Marcelle’s always had a penchant for being vindictive. This, combined with her wealth and position, makes her a force to be reckoned with.”

You find a quiet corner in the square to speak with Ludovico. It’s secluded and shady. 

Ludovico takes a deep breath before he begins.
“That…”
“That is an excellent idea madame. Please lead the way.”
“Is there anything this humble priest can help you with?”

Some time later, after you’ve waved away a particularly enthusiastic tea salesman for the third time, a familiar face emerges from behind the shadows of a tree. “Bonjour madame” he nods pleasantly. “You seem troubled.”

You get comfortable, smooth out your skirts and pause for a moment to reflect on the decisions that led you to a point in your life where you’re having secret rendezvous with priests to learn more about your hated enemies. If anything, they must have been some good decisions.

Looking around, you can’t spot Ludovico anywhere, so you decide to take a seat at the edge of the fountain. It makes sense to be visible enough that he’ll be able to find you without any flashy waving or signalling.

Surprisingly enough, you manage to find the fountain without getting turned around. It seems like the perfect place for a meeting like this. There’s just enough people wandering around that you won’t draw attention, but also few enough that you’ll be able to find somewhere secluded to talk.
Given that you’re still new to skullduggery, you’ve decided to dress in darker clothes, and have stuck to comfortable walking shoes.
You leave the house earlier than usual that morning, uncertain of how long it’ll take you to walk to the fountain that Ludovico mentioned in his letter to you.
“You’re a lot more devious than I expected you to be.”
“Merci Ludovico, your help means a lot to me.”
“Ludovico, if we’re being followed, our pursuers already know who we are.”
“Oh father, my woes are too terrible to discuss in a place like this. Perhaps we can go somewhere... private?”

Madame Mirror.asset.f1baab0500bfcac499e5:
He hurries away nervously, which seems good until you realize that he's still planning on trying to negotiate some kind of massive loan with you. 

The kind you can't possibly afford.
However, your first real priority is finding this mysterious woman who is pretending to be you.

You try to dismiss the thought but he's turned out to be quite insistent. Which makes sense, as anyone loaning money with a high interest rate is secretly hoping that you'll never be able to fully pay them back. Why else would they do it?
Talking with him a bit longer, you manage to both excuse yourself and convince him that you need a more time to think on this positively life ruining decision.
He talks with you a while longer, and it appears that he already intends to loan you a large sum of money. A sum so lage that you couldn't possibly pay it back.
"Madame, I'm sorry, but I need to leave immediately. We'll have to discuss your loans later." He replies, attempting to sound serious, but you can hear an undertone of panic in his voice.
"Why the only reason you'd ask that is... Oh no!"
"Then... if you aren't the one I spoke with then..."
(You have gained some credibility)
"What you were wearing?" He replies, feigning indulgent humor. "Such a curious question. Why would you ask that?"
"You haven't? Truly?"
"Uh... you look absolutely magnifique!" He replies, obviously caught offguard by your question. "It was quite the bold choice to change clothes in the middle of an event."
(You have lost a decent amount of credibility)
(You've gained a little credibility)
"If I may be so bold as to ask, why did you change your outfit?"
He steps back and looks you up and down, puzzled by something.
"Madame, are you serious? Have you forgotten about our deal already? I'm trusting you at your word with a princely sum of money. Please don't make me regret my trust."

"As I was saying, you approached me earlier in the evening and said that you were interested in borrowing a substantial amount of money. Of course, the interest rate will be significant, but you've already convinced me that this isn't worth worrying about."
(You have lost some credibility)
(You have gained a little peril)
"I'm glad to hear that you have everything in order! So many of my clients usually decide to barrage me with ceaseless questions."
"Are you serious? We just talked about this earlier today, Madame Yvette."
"You what?" He hisses at you. "Madame! Do not embarass me infront of this many notable clients. This isn't a time for joking."
He pauses to examine you for a moment, which makes sense. That lie could have been a little more confident.
You have no idea who the devil this is.
"Ah, Madame Decaux, I'm pleased to see you again! Would you be willing to indulge me for a moment, so we might be able to discuss our business again? You still remember everything we went over, non?"
You walk over to inspect said mirror, but you're interrupted by someone in the middle of your approach.

At first, you thought that you had been looking in a mirror, but something was simply off about the whole thing. 

How odd.
While circling the party, you happen to notice something very strange.
" Excusez-moi, but what was I wearing before?"
"Monsieur, I can assure you that I haven't changed my clothes."
"Better yet, what do you think of it?"
"I'm sorry, can you remind me of our business again?"
"Monsieur, I have no idea who you are."
"Ah, but of course! The business that we did... which I know so much about!"

"I'm so glad to see you. Armand, that ambitious little thing, has told me so much about you. In fact, I'd say that he's quite infatuated with you. A common girl like yourself... you're so lucky!"

She advances on you, close enough to feel the heat of her breath. “Let me be clear. You and your grasping, traitorous fiance are not guests in my home, nor will you ever be. I invited him here so I could express my displeasure to him in person.”
She pauses before speaking to you in a whisper loud enough for the entire room to hear. “Don’t worry, I don’t expect you to understand this.”
“...but now, I now have his cast off fiancee, who even had the audacity to lie to my face!”

“Nobody’s heard from your cowardly fiance in weeks, which is especially surprising, since he could never stop pestering his betters.” The crowd, which only seems to be growing, murmurs in agreement. “In fact, it’s been so long that I thought I was rid of him once and for all…”
“I mean, that’s because we both know Armand’s not sick.”
“Well I’m so glad you’re here, and I’m sure that he’ll be well soon.”
"Oh really, he insisted?" Marcelle trills and her dog yips happily.
"Trying to look like us? Act like us? Stop. You're just embarassing yourself."
“Now leave my estate, and never show your face here again.”

“Now pay attention, because I’d hate for you to miss the point. If you should ever find your wandering Armand, tell him that he is an unwelcome, conniving weasel. In fact, both of you should go back to your petty little village, and leave Paris to your superiors.”

Marcelle studies your face intently for a moment and her voice suddenly fills with concern. “Oh, you poor girl, don’t look so hurt! Think of this as educational. You don’t belong in Paris, the same way that a stray cat doesn’t belong in that dress.” She gestures dismissively at your finery.
A small cheer rings up from the crowd.

“Please pay attention, because I hate repeating myself. Your Armand is gone, off somewhere on another one of his foolish little political endeavors. However, if you should ever find him, tell him that he is an traitorous weasel, who should go back to whatever backwater he crawled out of, and leave the running of this country to his superiors.”

“Your Armand is a conniving, traitorous, opportunist who sullies the good name of the entire nobility just by being alive. The only reason he even chose a common girl like you to be his wife, is because any lady of good breeding would see him for the weasel that he is.”
“but now, I have this commoner, who doesn’t know her place either!”
“Now, not only do I find out that he’s a coward, who’s fled his fiance, and the consequences of his gall…”

“Armand, that ambitious little rat, was always reaching above his station. Always asking for people to listen to ideaa that nobody should even dare entertain! His audacity truly knew no bounds.” Her eyes are focused on you, but she’s speaking to the crowd, who seem to whisper in agreement. Even the dog regards you with malice.
“After all, you’ve already helped me!”

For a moment, the crowd hushes. You seem to have struck a nerve. Even the dog looks a little undone. “I suppose that when cornered, even a rat will think it’s a lion,” Marcelle whispers, her voice like ice.

Marcelle pauses to pet her dog. “I don’t know where he is. In fact, it’s a shame that Armand’s already scurried off somewhere. I was really hoping to tell him this to his face, but then again, he always was so good at disappointing people. You’ll have to do.”
“Why? While those craven nationalists in their dingy salons like to hide behind their pamphlets and newsletters, people of quality must be brave enough to denounce our enemies in person.”
“Yet here you are, with a fresh set of nuisances. Does this ever end?”

“I guess it makes sense that you’re here. Armand could never stop pestering his betters, so it feels rather appropriate that, even when sick, he’d send his peasant fiance to do it for him.” The crowd, which only seems to be growing, murmurs in agreement. “In fact, I almost thought I was rid of him once and for all…”
“I mean, I was hoping he’d show his face here, but you’ll do.”

Marcelle stares at you, concerned and shocked. “You don’t know where he is, and yet you still came to this little event of mine?” She gestures a free hand at the most splendid party you’ve ever seen in your life. “That is so kind of you, of course I’ll help!”

“That is so sweet of him!” Marcelle trills and her dog yips happily. “You’ve barely arrived from the country and he still wants you to meet all the people he’s been so fortunate to associate with. It’s very kind of you to represent him like this, and I’m sure that he’ll be well soon.”
“Where is Armand, by the way?”
A murmur of interest washes through the crowd, and you can feel their eyes focus on you.
Her voice raises in volume imperceptibly, but it’s enough to draw the attention of the large crowd in the room. “Everyone, this is Yvette, Armand’s fiancee!”

You nearly mistake the woman standing in front of you for some kind of walking confection. A pampered dog lounges in her arms. “I don’t believe we had the chance to properly introduce ourselves. I am Viscountess Marcelle de Foix.”
“I may be audacious, but at least I know how to treat my guests.”
“I’m guessing this means you don’t know where he is, either?”
“...why did you invite Armand here?”
“Poor Armand is ill at the moment, but he just insisted that I attend your party.”
“I may be a commoner, but at least I know how to treat my guests.”
“I’m guessing this means you don’t know where he is?”
“...why did you invite Armand here?”
“Do you always bemoan every ‘nuisance’ you send a handwritten invitation to?”
“...why did you invite Armand here?”
“That’s actually what I was hoping to find out. Do you know where I could find him?”

You hear some appreciative murmurs from other guests in the Vestibule. Your gratitude and enthusiasm seem to have made an impression on them, doing away with some of the tension in the air.

Surprisingly, the doorman himself seems rather unphased.
“Enjoy the party.” He says with a smile, before leaving.

Before you can ask any other questions, he bows deeply you to you. “Pardon moi, Madame. Viscountess de Foix instructed me specifically, to inform her as soon as you had arrived. We’ve heard so much about you.”
With a small flourish, you present a bottle of wine you had the forethought to bring earlier. It wasn’t cheap, but the gesture is more important.
“You must be quite upset, is there anything I can get you?”
The doorman’s eyes widen in surprise, that was certainly not the sort of answer he was expecting. “Oh my Madame, what an unfortunate turn of events.”

“Ah, that is most unfortunate.” the doorman replies, surprisingly disappointed. “The good Viscountess de Foix was so looking forward to seeing him tonight. Please convey our deepest regrets at his absence, our our well-wishes to his health.”
He glances about the room expectantly. “And… where may I find the good Baron?”

“Oui oui madame. I shall make sure that the Viscountess heards of it myself.” You hear some murmurs from other guests in the Vestibule. Your gratitude and enthusiasm seem to have made an impression on them, though the Doorman seems rather unphased.
“Is there anything I can get you?”
A moment later he composes himself. “Ah, I see, you are the Baron’s date. My apologies.”

He frowns at your irritation, but only for a moment. The doorman flips back and forth between the pages of his ledger before his finds what he’s looking for. “Ah yes! You are the date to Baron Armand de Marbo. If I so remember, you are his fiancée, non?”
“Ah, that is most unfortunate.” the footman replies, surprisingly disappointed. “Viscountess de Foix was so looking forward to seeing him tonight. Please convey our deepest regrets at his absence.”
The valet looks shocked. “Baron? Why are you dressed-”
The doorman looks perplexed at you for a moment, flipping through his ledger. “I do not see your name here, madame…”
“Name, Madame?” he asks expectantly.

When your carriage drops you off at the party, you find yourself waiting in line for quite some time. Looking at the other guests, you wonder if you're underdressed... or overdressed, it's honestly hard to tell.
“Baron Armand de Marbo.”
“Yvette Decaux.”
“Would you be able to take this gift of wine to our hostess?"
"Would you be able to take this gift of wine to our hostess?"
"Please convey my deepest gratitudes to our hostess, and tell her that I'm eager to meet her."
“That’s a good question, I wish I knew…”
“He has taken ill, but insisted that I attend in his stead.”
"Please convey my deepest gratitudes to our hostess, and tell her that I'm eager to meet her."
“Well then, look harder.”
“I am Baron Armand de Marbo’s date. He could not attend.”
Masks and Shadows.asset.094978ea0eb5b7a4: Camille returns, breathing heavily and carrying a basket full of various costume odds and ends. “It appears that monsieur Armand left behind a few masks when he departed. I’m sure one of them would be more than suitable. The masks themselves might be a little masculine, but perhaps that would make a fine contrast with your ensemble?”

The next few minutes are a cacophony of clatter as Camille frantically searches for an appropriate mask. A ceramic cup sails in and out of view through the open doorway to your bedroom. A small shattering sound marks it as yet another casualty in your quest for revenge.
You have an invitation. You have a mask. You have a birthday party that you just can’t wait to ruin.

Camille’s not wrong, you could make that work. Besides, the main purpose of the mask will be to conceal your identity.

It’s settled then.

“I believe Monsieur Armand left behind a few masks when he departed. I’m sure one of them would be more than suitable. The masks themselves might be a little masculine, but perhaps that would make a fine contrast with your ensemble?”
“Oui, madame!” Camille replies obediently, before leaving to search the house for something appropriately dramatic.
“Hmm…” Camille pauses to think, rubbing the hem of her apron between her thumb and forefinger.
Just then, Camille enters your room. “Good morning madame!”
You look down at the invitation on your nightstand and recognize it immediately as something Marcelle would send out. It’s the same shade of pink as the last ensemble you saw her in.
‘Hopefully, this shall make it easier for you to get the revenge you obviously deserve. Bien affectueusement, Honorade’

‘Hopefully, this shall make it easier for you to restore your lost honor. Très cordiales salutations, Alex’

‘Chère Yvette, I hope this letter finds you well, and that you’ve made satisfying progress in your quest for vengeance. It seems that we have been suitably discreet, as that vile wretch, Marcelle has seen fit to invite me to her masquerade ball.’

‘Chère Yvette, I hope this letter finds you in good spirits, and that you’ve made significant progress in your quest to reclaim your honor. It seems that we’ve been suitably discreet, as your treacherous enemy Marcelle has seen fit to invite me to her birthday masquerade ball.’

‘Chère Yvette, I hope this letter finds you well, and that you have made good progress in your quest for justice. It seems that we have been suitably discreet, as that vile woman Marcelle has seen fit to invite me to her birthday masquerade ball.’

You decide to read the letter first. It’s sealed with a rich, purple wax seal, bearing the initials “H.G.” It must be from Madame Gazel.

Opening it up, you catch the faintest scent of perfume, and another missive from her, written in flowing cursive.

You decide to read the letter first. It’s sealed in pristine blue wax with the initials “T-A.D.”. It must be from Alex.

Opening it up, you find another missive from him, written in his precise penmanship.

You decide to read the letter first. It’s sealed in golden wax with the initials “L.S.” It must be from Ludovico.

Opening it up, you find another missive from him, written in his steady, well practiced handwriting.
You wake up to find two things on your nightstand: a letter sealed in wax, and a gaudy invitation printed on pink paper. Camille must have put them there while you were asleep.
“Camille, I need to ruin someone’s birthday party. Fetch me a mask, immediately.”

Maximin Appears.asset.7327864d51f371847a: (You have lost a little credibility)
(You have lost some credibility)

(You have gained quite a bit of credibility)
(You have gained a little favor with members of the Crown)

“Your cowardly fiance could have spent his time doing something useful, like echoing the views of his betters. Instead he chose to waste our time with calls to consider traitorous, 'alternative actions'. We don’t need to tolerate this kind of intellectual and moral threat. Both of you should do the right thing and skulk back to wherever you came from, in silence.”
“Of course, it’s a shame your loyalty is anchored to such mediocrity, but still...”

“Your loyalty to Armand is commendable, and exactly the sort of thing we’re striving to bring to this troubled nation of ours.”

A small cheer goes up from some of the crowd.

“It’s been days since anyone’s heard from the Baron de Marbo. Originally, I’d taken it as a blessing that we no longer had to deal with his ignorant and traitorous declarations. However, now I find myself face to face with his fiancee, who isn’t just ignorant, but a liar!”
“Unless, of course, he’s not actually sick.”

Maximin chuckles, “Of course, this gathering is more of a salon than a party, but I can see why you would be confused.” He reaches out and pats your hand. “Please don’t be embarrassed, I’m sure Armand will be able to explain the differences later, when he’s feeling better.”

"I must say that I’m surprised that Armand thinks so highly of true, revolutionary minds.” Murmurs of appreciation and agreement ripple through the crowd, but are quickly hushed by other guests, who are also pretending that they’re not listening in.

“Tell your Baron de Marbo to stay in his sick bed. It is a blessing for all of France that we no longer have to deal with his ignorant and traitorous declarations.” He emphasizes his point by slapping one of his pamphlets against his thigh. “Who knows? Perhaps if the two of you read enough, you might be able to stop embarrassing yourselves.”
“You’ve lost him?” Maximin asks, a sudden note of confusion marring his features. “And you came here?”
"Oh, really?"
“I’ve been told that Armand is unable to join us tonight. What has delayed him?”

“Ah, you must be Madame Decaux! I’m not sure if Armand spoke of me, I am Baron Maximin de Termes.” Right as he focuses his attention on you, you can feel everyone in the room watching you out of the corners of their eyes. His opinion must carry a great deal of weight.
“Titles don’t elevate us above consequences. Now, leave my house and never return.”
“You are a fool for believing that, and he is a fool for loving you.”
“Like a barnacle... or a leech.”

“Our associations reflect our character, and you have chosen to associate yourself with a dangerous boor who drags at the heels of true progress in France. I can only assume that you are a craven opportunist who thought that marrying into a title would provide an easy path above her peers. That your life would be easy, if you just found the right person to latch onto.”
“You are wrong.”
He takes a step towards you, and you can see that his eyes are filled with hate. “Now still your childish tongue. The adults are talking.”

The Baron takes a breath to recompose himself and snort derisively. “Well actually, if you’d taken the time to read any of the materials I just gave you, then you’d know that calls for civility are the enemy of progress.”

“And you…” he continues “I don’t need to investigate you any further to know that you are cut from the same wretched cloth.” 

The room is quiet enough to hear a pin drop.

“The only reason I even invited him was to save myself the time of authoring a pamphlet denouncing him.” Maximin snorts “He, and his regressive ideas of 'alternative action'. In a time of such turmoil in our country, only decisive action has any meaning. To believe otherwise is to be a coward, and a slave to the enemies of the people.”
Maximin’s voice drops low, to a growl barely above a whisper, “Before you speak, I already know what you’re thinking. That somehow, you don’t deserve this…”

“His wild and unseemly ideas make him an enemy of the revolution, an enemy of the common people of France, and an enemy of mine. The only thing he can do to atone for his miserable views is to take you, and return to the backwards obscurity from whence he came!”
Maximin narrows his eyes until they’re barely more than slits. “In fact, you can practice this virtue now and make sure that he hears this, should you manage to find him.”
You hear a collective intake of breath from the gawking crowd. Maximin seems on the verge of a retort, but he stutters for a moment instead.
“I do not know where he has skulked off to, nor am I inclined to find him.”

“I invited your dullard fiance in order to denounce him and his views. People like himself should not waste their time clouding discussions with their dangerous ignorance. They’re better served by repeating the words of their more revolutionary peers.”
“If he’s lost then it means we no longer have to entertain his traitorous ideas.”

With a flood of realization he laughs “Oh, but of course! You’re just here, at my salon, to find your Armand! I thought you were here for our enlightened discourse but… no, this makes much more sense.”
The crowd is no longer making a secret of observing your conversation. They’re gawking.
“In fact, when you do that, I have a message for him. Write this down, if you can.”

Maximin chuckles, “Of course, this gathering is more of a salon than a party, but I can see why you would be confused.” He reaches out and pats your hand. “Please don’t be embarrassed, I’m sure Armand will be able to explain the differences later, when he’s feeling better.”

“That’s fantastic to hear! I’m surprised that Armand thinks so highly of true, revolutionary minds.” Murmurs of appreciation and agreement ripple through the crowd, but are quickly hushed by other guests, who are also pretending that they’re not listening in.
Maximin pauses, his eyes sweeping the room for a moment. “But please, I must trouble you with a question of my own.”

“In fact, you may both find these useful!” He grabs a jumbled stack of political pamphlets off of his desk and hands them to you. “Discourse moves so rapidly after all, and I would hate for the two of you to have any trouble keeping up.”

A few voices in the crowd murmur in approval.

“It’s great to meet the woman Armand spoke so much of. He said more about you than he did the state of the nation, and you know much he loves that.” Maximin smiles and offers a knowing wink. “Now that I’ve seen you, I can see why he had such muddled priorities.”

“But please, let us dispense with titles, you may call me Maximin!”

The crowd chuckles, and you can’t help but be surprised by this noble’s informality. This would be downright scandalous in any other circle. The conversations in the various corners of the room die down as people strain to hear your exchange with Maximin.

Out of the corner of your eye, you notice a tall, thin man dressed in somber, serious colors. The way people are clustered around him, you get the feeling that he’s quite important. He glances up from his current conversation, politely excuses himself, and approaches you.
"I actually don't know, Maximin. I don't even know where he is."
"I'm sorry, but Armand has taken ill. Still, he said that I just had to attend your party."
“Are you even listening to yourself? Because I am, and I wish I wasn’t.”
"You don't know where he is either, then?"
"...if he was so mediocre, why did you invite him?"
“I don’t need your pamphlets to know that you’re being a presumptuous boor.”
"...why invite Armand if you disliked him so?"

Pierre puts down his snuff box and favors you with a deep and theatrical bow. "Now you flatter me madame. Bonne chance madame, and may God see fit to reunite you with your Armand in great haste."
“I like to think we’ve made good business partners, non?”
“But please, enough about such ignoble matters, you are here to learn of your fiance, non?”
While the empty liquor bottles laying on the ground make you doubt his honesty a little, you get the feeling that he isn’t going to budge on this.

He gestures to his dilapidated and stained office. “However, while the pursuit of truth may make a man virtuous, it does not make him wealthy. The coins I give are all I can spare, as I need all that remains to keep the wheels of my press turning.”

Pierre scowls at you for a fraction of a second, before breaking out into a wide and almost-sympathetic grin. “Madame, but if only I could! I would pay for your gracious insights with bars of silver, and fistfuls of rubies, as that is what they are worth!”
“Merci beaucoups, madame…” he sighs, pausing to inhale a heavy pinch of snuff. “But please, enough about my troubles, you are here to learn of your fiance, non?”
“I needed you because most of my sources have taken their business to other… less esteemed publications.”

“I can’t just print gossip that’s been sold to everyone else. My readers expect something unique in these pages, not the same unoriginal tripe bandied about in those… lesser papers.”

You find yourself slightly taken aback by the sincerity in Pierre’s voice.

“Journals like my own have always existed in one… unofficial capacity or another, but with the end of royal censorship, new papers are opening every day! The competition for readership, and for new information, has become ridiculous!” Pierre throws up his hands in exasperation.

He hands you the paper, it’s an address. "The Guet Royal raided the studio a month ago and arrested everyone there. While supporting the Queen is certainly not a crime, something about this group's beliefs was making someone in power very uncomfortable. The studio has been abandoned ever since. Go there, and you might find something that leads you to your Armand.”

"There’s a studio in the seventh arrondissement where he and some like minded individuals preferred to discuss the 'proper' course for the country. Painters in the front, planning in the back." Pierre starts scribbling on a piece of paper.

“Now, before you leave madame, I hope that you do not forget about me and my humble paper. I still find your social insights valuable, and I’m stilling willing to pay for anything you can bring to me.”

"While the details of their beliefs have been remarkably difficult to track down, I know two things about their views. Pierre sighs and mops the sweat from his brow with a severely stained handkerchief. “To be honest madame, I am in a bit of a tough situation.”

"It may shock you to learn that your Armand managed to keep some rather… opinionated company." Pierre says with the careful circumspection of someone severely downplaying the seriousness of a situation.
“Now, I assume, you wish to know more about your beloved Armand, non?”
Pierre claps his hands together in delight, “Madame, it appears that you have done me a great service! With all of this gossip together, I can finally launch my most comprehensive social piece yet!”

On the other hand, the priests in the country have watched their parishes starve, and support the Revolution, or at least its ideals.
"Over the last few months, I've written many letters back to Rome, and lately I've found myself in a difficult spot."
The two of you walk in silence for a while. You try to pretend it isn't an awkward silence, but the attempt is only partly succesful.
"My apologies, Yvette. I'll try to be more thoughtful next time..."
"That's good. I was worried that I'd done something terrible."
"I'm so sorry. Have I upset you?"
He takes the book back from you. "I'll destroy this, as soon as I get home."
"What? I know I'm not the best priest, but I have to at least try sometimes."
Now that you're seeing the level of information at your finger tips, you're getting excited. This is a valuable book. Valuable indeed.
"Still, I'm so glad that you like it." He glances around to make sure that you're both alone. "Let me show you a few interesting things."
"I've had all the protections of being a priest, for so long that I forgot that others aren't as lucky as I am."
"I've already committed all of my notes to memory, so I felt it would be better in your hands than my own."
"Why? Because I trust you, Yvette. Because I know you're ambitious and I want to help."
"Oh, I didn't even think about that."
"Please Yvette, I've done good work, but let's not take the Lord's name in vain."
This is a spy's goldmine.

You start finding pages where the margins have been filled with densely packed notes. However, these notes aren't about the book or its characters. These are notes on the most prominent people in Paris.
Equal parts curious and suspicious, you page through the book. At first you don't notice anything, but suddenly...
"Open it up."
He gestures to his cassock. "Obviously, my situation didn't allow for me to follow his example, but such is life, and we do what we can."
"But that's not all," He says in a low voice.
"Will you at least give it a try? If not, I won't pester you about this. The story itself isn't important."

"When it was written, everyone saw it as a comedy about a fanciful madman. Then, years later, readers started to see it as a tragedy about a well meaning eccentric, ridiculed and ground down by an overly serious society."
"Absolutely, I fell in love with his work years ago. I've especially enjoyed seeing how the meaning of the book has changed over time."
"Oh, is it not?" He asks with a certain amount of apprehension.
"It's an adventure, it's a comedy, and there's also some delightfully biting social commentary. In short, it's my favorite kind of story. I'll always treasure Quixote's sense of romance."
"I originally started reading it in French to learn the language faster, but it's always been a favorite of mine."

Finally, he pulls a worn leather book out of his bag and hands it to you. The lamp light catches on the gilted lettering on the cover.

'Don Quixote' reads the title.
He starts rummaging through his bag, looking for something. "I have a present for you."
"Ah yes! I almost forgot!" Ludovico suddenly yelps.
After your rendezvous, Ludovico offers to walk you home. Soon, you find yourself chatting and laughing together, as you stroll home under the glow of the city lamps.

You're starting to wonder if this investigation will ever start answering more questions than it asks.

"Merci beaucoups!" She yelps in relief. "I promise to never keep anything from you again!"
"I'm so sorry madame! I never wanted to lie to you. I just... I just..."

"I was supposed to tell you what happened, but this house is just so big and empty... by the time you arrived, I was so lonely. I was afraid that if you knew the whole story then you'd leave, and I'd be alone again."

"Monsieur Armand managed to fight them off, but he was hurt and thought that these men would come back for him. So, packed his things, wrote the note for you, and left. He thought that if he wasn't here, they'd keep chasing after him and you'd be safe."

You look over the signet ring that was included in the box. It's a finely made silver ring with a signet used for pressing seals in wax. You don't recognize the symbol on the ring, but the piece of jewelry itself looks very old.
"Now, I still have to make you lunch, so I'm going to have to ask you to leave the kitchen."

Before you can ask any further questions, Camille ushers you out, into the hallway. The door shuts quickly behind you and all you can hear is the clattering of pots and pans as she starts furiously preparing food.
"Madame, I simply don't know what you're talking about." Camille replies in a rush, fidgeting with her apron.

"A few weeks ago, when Monsieur Armand still lived here... some men came here in the middle of the night. I don't know why but they tried to hurt him." Camille says, her voice low and afraid. "I was in the cellar getting wine, so I hid down there in the dark until the screaming stopped."
"Why did he leave?" She asks nervously.
For the first time, you feel like Camille might not be telling the truth.

I remember her because she always wore a silver necklace, with the prettiest emerald in the center of it."

"Madame, what’s going on?"

"I was just about to start making lunch…" Camille says, pointing awkwardly at the stove.

You look inside the bag… that’s a lot of coins.

Inside the box you find a magnetic compass, a map of Paris with notes concerning when the guards change at every one of the city gates, a signet ring, and a leather bag heavy with coins.
You pull up the floorboards and fish around in the dark until you find a small wooden box, held shut by a padlock. You open it with the key you found behind the painting.

Heading downstairs, you walk into the kitchen. It’s clean but cramped, and Camille keeps it well stocked with fresh produce. You find the stove, made of dark iron and standing on a set of clawed feet. 

Alone, on your hands and knees, you feel around until you find a set of loose floorboards.

You turn over the letter and find no additional writing, no additional context or explanation. 

Who is Johanna? How long has Armand known her for? Is she one of the people he’d been writing back home?

‘Your partner in conspiracy,

Johanna’

‘If fortune turns against us, then I want you to flee Paris entirely, and head to the border. If you show them my ring then our sponsors will protect you. 'Cher Armand, I will always appreciate your commitment to our cause, and I know France will be better for it. However, our chance of being caught grows with every passing day. I will not waste ink painting terrible pictures of the consequences, as you are already familiar with them.'

You don't recognize the handwriting, but decide against taking the time to read the note now, while illegally trespassing in a condemned building. You carefully fold the note around the key and secret it under your stays.

You'll be able to investigate it later.
“Come with me, we’re going to the watch post, and you’ll have plenty of time to come up with a better excuse as to why we found you in building ordered closed by the King.”
He sighs and pinches the bridge of his nose. “Non, I don’t have the time for this. Come with me, we’re going to the watch post, and you’re going to explain this to someone who cares.”
“In fact, it’s so good, that you can tell everyone down at the watch post all about it…”
“Do you have any earthly idea how many times I’ve heard that?” He asks, his face switching to an expression of tired disapproval.
“Your… fiance?” He asks, incredulous for a moment. “You’re looking for your fiance, in the middle of the night, in a building ordered closed by the king?”
“Lost, eh? That’s a good story.” He says, his voice even, but stern.
“You! Put your hands in the air! What are you doing here?”

With a crash and the sound of splintering wood, you can hear the door being kicked open.

“Halt, in the name of the king!” someone shouts into the building.
The pounding of boots is getting louder and louder. The Guet Royal are here.
Without even a look back, you disappear into the dark alley you initially approached the studio from.

Outside, you fastidiously put the boards back where you found them on the window. Your ears perk up at the sound of approaching footsteps, and you spot the reflection of lantern light off of nearby buildings. The Guet Royal are on their way, but as long as you keep moving, you should be gone before they arrive.
While the authorities may be none the wiser of your deeds, you curse the circumstances that led you to this dead end. With your bodyguard are your back, you disappear into the night.
“After you, madame.” Hansel gestures towards the dark alley you initially approached the studio from.

Outside, he puts the boards back on the window where he found them. You can hear approaching footsteps, and spot the reflection of lantern light off of nearby buildings. The Guet Royal are on there way, but as long as you keep moving, you should be gone before they arrive.

“Monsieurs, Gott sei dank! Someone has stolen my house!”
Hansel exits through the window you both entered from and jogs up the street towards the approaching authorities, you can already hear him shouting at them, slurring his words like a drunk.
“This should buy you some time, madame.”

With that, Hansel pulls out a flask of brandy from his coat and pours it all over himself. He then rumples his coat, doing up a few of the buttons into the wrong holes, and rumples his hair until he looks truly disheveled.

Quickly and quietly, you skulk to the window you entered the building through. Peering through the window, it seems like the coast is clear for now. You lever yourself out the window, and into the street.

“Ja, madame.” Hansel grunts with a sound of frustration that echoes your own. He leads you to the window you entered the building through. He effortlessly helps you out the window before following you out, scanning the street for witnesses.
“Stall them, Madame?” Hansel asks with a cocked eyebrow. “Hmmm… I think I have something that should do the trick.”
“We don’t have long before they arrive. What should we do, madame?”
You don’t have much time before they arrive, a few minutes at most.
“Gottverdammt! The Guet Royal are on their way. Someone must have spotted us and summoned them.” Hansel growls, scanning the various avenues of approach.
Someone must have spotted you and summoned the Guet Royal. If they find you here, they will most certainly arrest you.
Your ears perk up at the sound of voices. They’re distant, but it feels like they’re headed in this direction. Glancing out a window, you see the flicker of lantern light on nearby buildings.
Having learned everything you can from the back room, you decide to search elsewhere.
Having learned everything you can from the painting studio, you decide to search elsewhere.

Outside, he puts the boards back on the window where he found them. You can hear approaching footsteps, and spot the reflection of lantern light off of nearby buildings. The Guet Royal are on there way, but as long as you keep moving, you should be gone before they arrive.
With a precious lead in your possession, and the authorities none the wiser, you vanish into the night.
Without even a look back, you disappear into the dark alley you initially approached the studio from.

Outside, you fastidiously put the boards back where you found them on the window. Your ears perk up at the sound of approaching footsteps, and you spot the reflection of lantern light off of nearby buildings. The Guet Royal are on there way, but as long as you keep moving, you should be gone before they arrive.

“Ja, madame.” Hansel grunts as you give the signal to leave, leading you to the window you entered the building through. He effortlessly helps you out the window before following you out, scanning the street for witnesses.

Quickly and quietly, you skulk to the window you entered the building through. Peering through the window, it seems like the coast is clear for now. You lever yourself out the window, and into the street.
You can’t help but grin with satisfaction. This is the lead you were looking for.

You turn the painting back and forth looking for more details, until you hear something metallic shift. Flipping the painting over, you find a note tucked into the frame on the back of painting, along with a key.

Armand’s smiling face is looking back at you from the picture, a glass raised in mid toast, and a quill in his free hand. On one side of him is a man you remember from your last night together with Armand. The man is named Isaac. On the other side of him, is a young woman, with strawberry blonde hair, who you’ve never seen before. Her hand is on his shoulder.

It’s a dining scene, done in a reflected perspective intended to make the actual room feel larger than it really is. All the men and women in the picture are laughing, clinking glasses and looking merry. 

Even Armand.
The rest of the unburned scraps look too small or unclear to provide you with any additional information.
‘-and de Marbo’, written in familiar handwriting on a fragment of paper. Armand was here, perhaps in this very room. Maybe there’s something else connected to him nearby.

You pick through the ashes, finding fragments of leather and scraps of unburned paper. The writing on the paper is handwritten, not printed. It looks like a list of names. A membership list?

That’s when you spot it.
You find nothing else of value under the circular table.
While you’re sure this reading list is insightful, it won’t bring you closer to finding Armand.

Eventually, you can deduce a meaning from the scratchings. All the notes are suggested readings, various books and pamphlets. They seem to cover a broad range of texts related to history and political theory. While some of the authors are French, you notice that most of them are from elsewhere in the continent, especially in central Europe.

Stepping over the ash in front of the fireplace, you gingerly take the painting off of its hook and examine it closely. It’s not as carefully detailed as some of the others in the building, but there’s a certain joyful energy to it. Whoever painted this genuinely enjoyed making it.

You bend down carefully, making sure you don’t kneel in the large swath of ashes in front of the fireplace. A cold breeze blows at your back and you look up at the charred hole in the roof of the building. This fire must have gotten large enough to set a portion of the ceiling ablaze. It’s a miracle this building is still standing at all.

Whoever started this fire didn’t have time to do things properly, they just needed something burned.
No. Wait. It’s just terrible handwriting.

You find a small scattering of coins. It appears that, at some point in the chaos, someone must have dropped their coin purse, and nobody noticed it. It doesn’t bring you closer to Armand, but you’ll never turn down free coin.
You bend down to investigate under the table, trying to find what caught the light of your lantern and glimmered at you from the dark.
You lean close to the notes on the wall, and squint to read them. None of them make any sense, as if they were written in another language, or some kind of code.
You feel like you’ve learned everything you can from the paintings in this room.
Looking at the paintings, you feel like you’ve learned something about the artists here, but nothing useful about Armand. You’ll have to search somewhere he would have spent a lot of time in.
You rummage through the papers, but it seems like everything useful has already been taken.
You scan the second floor, deciding what to investigate.
What are you going to investigate in the back room?

Inside, the back room is cramped, mostly occupied by a circular table with some small chairs. Various notes are pinned to the wall, and as you shine your lantern about, you notice a slight glimmer under the table.

The paintings on the wall are all traditional historical pieces, exactly the sort of thing L’Academie exalts as ‘true art’. Judging by the stern faces and repeated images, you’re sure that the paintings are all meant to be some kind of political allegory, but you can’t really tell what of.

The desk by the door is so beautiful that it seems to clash with the rough practicality of the other furniture in the room. All of the drawers have been flung open, and papers have been scattered everywhere.
Scanning the painting studio, you try to determine what you’ll investigate.
“Where should we look?”
Hansel steps in front of you and whispers. “Now that we have a light in here, it’s only a matter of time before someone spots us. I recommend we move quickly, madame.”
Now that you have a little more light, you can see that most of the furniture inside is broken, and enough things are missing to make you wonder how much the Guet Royal seized during their raid.

Inside, the studio is even darker than you would have guessed. Between the boards on the windows, and the lack of lighting in the surrounding street, it’s nearly impossible to pick out any detail smaller than the walls and doors.

You carefully use a flint stowed in the base of your lantern to light it, then muffle most of the light with the hem of your cloak.

The stairs creak underneath your feet as you make your way to the second floor. The long table and scattered cutlery suggests that it was used as a dining area. A small fireplace occupies one side of the room, with a wide swath of ash spilling out of the fireplace and onto the floor. Above the fireplace itself, a painting hangs on the mantle.

The entrance to the back room isn’t obvious and if Pierre hadn’t told you about it earlier, you might have mistaken it for a closet door. When you go to open the door, you notice that the latch has been torn off. Probably a casualty of the raid.
Your time is limited, where do you plan on searching for clues?

Now that you have a little more light, you can see that most of the furniture inside is broken, and enough things are missing to make you wonder how much the Guet Royal seized during their raid. It’s also only a matter of time before someone spots you and comes to investigate.

From your position outside, you peer into the gloom and watch Hansel examine the room for a few moments before he gives a satisfied nod, dropping his hand from his weapon. Returning to the window, he grabs you by the waist, and easily helps you into the building.

He enters the building first, his face frozen in a grim expression that almost makes you feel bad for any dangerous persons you might encounter.

Almost.
You get Hansel’s attention, and he quietly takes down the boards, leaving them in a neat pile by the window to be put back later.

Now that you’re closer, you can see that the door has been nailed shut. Wordlessly, you and Hansel start checking the boards on the windows, seeing if any of them are loose. On the third window, you find one of boards easily gives way, like it’s been pulled out before.

Someone else has been here.

The mercenary crouches down and places his hand on the grip of his sabre. You hike up your skirts, and get ready to follow him. On his signal, you quietly dash across the street together, watching for any movement in the windows as your approach.
When you get to the window, Hansel’s hands emerge from the darkness and grab you by the waist, easily helping you into the building.
After what feels like an eternity, you see his hand emerge from the opened window and motion for you to approach. You hike up your skirts and quietly hurry across the street towards him.

Hansel gazes warily at the building before turning back to you. For a moment he looks like he’s about to object, but your mind is obviously made up. 

“Understood, madame. We go together.”

Eventually, he finds that some of the boards covering one of the windows are loose, quietly pries them off, and easily hops through the window into the building inside. You catch glimpses of him through some of the other windows as he scouts out the darkened interior.

Crouching as low as his sizeable frame will allow, Hansel advances towards the building with his hand firmly on the grip of his sabre. He glances inside the windows and tries the door, which appears to be have been nailed shut.
“Madame, I’d like to inspect the building first. You never know who’s taken up residence in empty places like this.”

Inside, the studio is even darker than you would have guessed. Between the boards on the windows, and the lack of lighting in the surrounding street, it’s nearly impossible to pick out any detail smaller than the walls and doors.

You carefully use a flint stowed in the base of your lantern to light it, then muffle most of the light with the hem of your cloak.

You carefully ease yourself through the window, making sure none of your clothes get caught on any exposed nails. Once inside, you close your eyes for a few moments, so they’ll adjust to the darkness faster.
Gingerly, you take down each of the boards, leaving them in a neat pile by the window to be put back later. Secrets are easier to uncover when nobody knows that you’re looking at all.

Leaning back and craning your neck to examine the roof, you see there’s a hole big enough for you to enter the building through, but you don’t have a ladder, or any way to get up there. For a moment you consider trying to enter the building next door, so you can drop down onto the roof, but it’s better to do this as quickly as possible.

Putting down your unlit lantern, you start checking the boards on the windows, seeing if any of them are loose. On the third window, you find one set of boards easily gives way, like it’s been pulled out before.

Someone else has been here.
You immediately notice that the door’s been nailed shut.
Rather than stand around in the middle of a dark street, you hike up your skirts and hurry across the road to the studio.
Glancing around, you don’t see anyone at all, as if the King’s notice somehow closed the entire street.
Before you can step any further towards the closed building, Hansel steps in front of you.

Rounding a corner, you find yourself on an empty street, looking across the road at the studio. The windows of the small, two storey building have been boarded up, and there’s a charred hole in the roof. A sign nailed to the door reads ‘Closed! On orders of the King.’

Rounding a corner, you find yourself on an empty street, looking across the road at the studio. The windows of the small, two storey building have been boarded up, and there’s a charred hole in the roof. A sign nailed to the door reads ‘Closed! On orders of the King.’

Winding your way through the streets of the seventh arrondissement, you can’t help but think about how out of the way this place would have been for Armand. Yet, Pierre said that he was still a regular visitor. Despite yourself, you find your heart beating faster and faster as you get closer to the abandoned studio.

You waited for sunset before you headed out, as it feels like these sort of things are better done under the cover of darkness. However, everything still feels too bright. Every hanging lantern, every candle-lit window, feels like an eye staring down at you.

The front of the building is the painting studio, the floors spattered with pigments, and still littered with the scraps of various art supplies. An ornate desk sits in the front of the room, near the door, with papers scattered all around it. A few finished canvases still remain on the walls, though it looks like a lot of the others were either seized or destroyed.

Tugging on the edges of your hood to make sure your face is hidden from view, you glance down again at the hastily scribbled address Pierre gave you in his office. In addition to your regular traveling clothes, you have a small bag hanging off of your shoulder, and a portable lantern with a flint.
“This isn’t what it looks like.”
“Monsieur, I’m looking for my fiance.”
“Well, as you can tell, I’m terribly lost.”
“I think it’s time to leave.”
"I'm not leaving here empty handed."
“It’s time to leave, Hansel.”
“Hansel, I need you to stall them.”
“Stay with me, I’m not leaving this place empty handed.”

The Bishop of Autun.asset.32f83136b35f09: Of course, this has caused some uproar, as Talleyrand has never even been to Autun. Ignoring his critics, he spent the evening celebrating this turn of good fortune by dining with his mistress in the Louvre.
It appears that the traditionalists in the Church have won this day, and the Revolution has lost the chance to have a powerful ally.

(The Church has gained some power)
(The Church has moved towards the Crown a little)
And so, in Paris, life goes on.

(The Church has lost a little power)
(The Church has moved towards the Revolution by a decent amount)
The Revolution has gained a powerful ally within the Church, but the credibility of the Church has been damaged, for reasons that don't require divine insight to perceive.

A few days ago, his pious prayers were answered, and the Bishop of Autun moved to Leon. This opening has made made Talleyrand the new bishop, and given him all of the power he wanted. This includes a wealth of property, and a salary of nearly fifty thousrand livres a year.

Unfortunately for him, it seems that Talleyrand's prayers have gone unanswered. While the Bishop of Autun has moved to Lyon, he's selected a different successor to his post. This has left the ambitious Talleyrand fuming, and the more orthodox members of the clergy laughing behind their hands.

However, actual advancement within the Church has evaded him for some time. While it's well known that he's been impatiently waiting for the Archbishop of Bourges to finally join the heavenly host, Talleyrand has also had his eye on the post of the Bishop of Autun.

While he's fulfilled his duties to the Church well, he's also been the subject of much scandal. Talleyrand believes that he embodies a modern system of Catholic values, including his preferences towards the needs of the common people over the nobility. However, these modern views seem to be dismissive of his vows of celibacy. Despite the infirmities that caused his family to dismiss him, he's still been considered quite desirable by many women in France, due to his kindness, erudition, and snapping witicisms.

Charles-Maurice de Talleyrand-Périgord, or simply 'Talleyrand' is figure of much discussion in France. Born as the scion to a powerful noble family, his foot was maimed at an early age in an accident. Unable to particapte in the courtly dances of the courtiers, or march adequately enough to serve in the military, he was deemed useless by his family. Thus, he was sent into the priesthood, like many unwanted sons of nobility.
The Bourgeois Militia.asset.d5000438a814: The situation is dire, but surely, everyone will be more reasonable than that, right?
Of course, that would be utterly insane. Nobody would try to storm a castle in the middle of Paris. That would plunge the city into the kind of chaos that one could never turn back from.
And so, in Paris, life goes on.

This militia could overwhelm and rob the ocassional group of watchmen, or even a small military checkoint, but the only large concentration of weaponry that you can think of in Paris is the Bastille. The imposing castle used to be a major prison, but now it's mostly an armory that happens to hold a few especially odious criminals in its spare cells.

Then again, a large amount of angry people doesn't make an army. While Paris certainly contains enough sickles, kitchen knives, and hammers to allow for violent mobs, any uprising would need rifles and even cannons to succeed.

Those tend to be in short supply.

If that wasn't disturbing enough, it's well known at this point that this militia will have no shortage of volunteers. While there aren't many fears of large scale desertion within the military, there are still a lot of angry citizens out there, and it doesn't take a lot of manpower to throw up a barricade in the streets and start trouble.

If that wasn't disturbing enough, it's well known at this point that this militia will have no shortage of volunteers. There are already fears that members of the military will desert to this new army, as they no longer feel any particular loyalty to the Crown.

Today, the members of the National Assembly publicly called for the creation of a 'Bourgeois Militia'. 

They want their own army.
Only two days ago, Prime Minister Necker was suddenly dismissed by the king. It was a decision that did not sit well with most.
The Cardinal Sin.asset.b96e207d2cae30646: (You have acquired some gossip. This will be useful later.)
(You have lost some credibility)
(You have gained a little peril)
(You have acquired some gossip. This will be useful later.)

The two of them disappear to a more secluded section of the party, watching you carefully all the while. 

You have a feeling they didn’t believe you.

“Well, if you did actually grow up there, you must be more familiar with the facts than us.” The older man demures, already pulling his friend away by the elbow. “We would hate to supply you with any misinformation.”

He puts a strong emphasis on the word ‘supply’.

The younger man examines you carefully before he says “That’s quite an unusual accent you have, for someone who grew up in Grenoble.”

Your mind races, and you’re not sure if you can remember what a Grenoble accent even sounds like.
"I can understand why, madame. It was grizzly enough that the church didnt make any official announcements. The archbishops funeral was closed casket because-"

During your conversation, you manage to get a few more details about the time of death, who discovered the body, and more. This is exactly what you were hoping for. A rumor, by itself, isn’t of any consequence. Specific details add an air of truthfulness which is necessary for quality gossip. This should be valuable to someone.

“I suppose he’s right.” The younger man admits. “What’s most important is that archbishop’s death was a suicide, and this made the church extremely uncomfortable. This is why they were so quiet about his passing.”
You continue your hushed conversation with the two men, and manage to tease out a few more specifics. The three of you eventually go your separate ways.
This is exactly the level of detail you were hoping for. A rumor, by itself, isn’t of any consequence. Gruesome details, on the other hand, make for fine gossip. This should be valuable to someone.

“The archbishop of Grenoble shot himself.” The younger man says flatly. “It was a suicide, and a particularly gruesome one at that. That’s why he was in a closed casket instead of being laid out properly. It was also why the church was so unwilling to divulge the details of his death.”
“Don’t worry, such details are unnecessary to understanding the bigger picture.” The older man says in an a patronizing tone.
After a long pause, the older man relents. “Fine, if you must know...”
“I would not want to offend the madame’s sensibilities with such dreadful details.”
The older guest stops his friend mid sentence. “I’m not sure if we should continue.”

The two of them disappear to a more secluded section of the party, watching you carefully all the while. 

You have a feeling that you’ll be watched more closely from now on.
Before you can answer, his older friend chimes in. “Perhaps we should take our conversation elsewhere. I doubt that we’ll find any privacy here.”

You hear a throat clear.

“Can we help you, madame?” The younger man asks you, with a suspicious scowl.
However, this does give you the level of detail you were hoping for. A rumor, by itself isn’t valuable. Details, on the other hand, make for fine gossip. This should be valuable to someone.

“Well that would certainly explain why it was a closed casket affair. There mustn’t have been much of him left, after that.” 

Your mind conjures up a gruesome image, entirely against your will, and you wretch internally at it.
“I hear that he loaded two bullets in his pistol before he… did it.”
“For a many of the cloth to commit the cardinal sin? It is the only explanation.”
“He must have felt some guilt for everything that happened.” The older man ventures.

You decide against engaging them in conversation, or listening in. While it’s nice to have some reliable gossip, you don’t need it that badly right now. Instead, you spend some time wandering about the party, sipping at your wine, taking in the sights and the sounds.

The men are speaking to each other in low voices, and it’s difficult to hear them over the din of the party. You edge a little closer to listen to them, pretending to scan the party as if you were looking for a friend that got lost in the crowd.
They turn, noticing you for the first time.
If you could learn more, this might be some truly valuable gossip.

“That he'd killed himself after the riots. Yes, even I found that distressing.”

You’d heard that too, but it was only a rumor. The Church never confirmed this, but why would they?
The older man replies wearily “Agreed, and the bloodshed was monstrous. Did you hear about their Bishop?”

The younger one sighs, and gestures to the crowd with his wine glass. “Everyone’s talking about reforming the estates as if it’s going to be as simple as making a request. Does nobody remember what happened in Grenoble? They sent soldiers into that town just for trying to hold a meeting.”
You happen upon a pair of men whispering in a corner together. They’re trying to look as happy and engaged as the other guests, but they’re movements are too stiff. They seem concerned.
“Perhaps you are right. It may be too much for me.”
“Please monsieur, I need to know.”
<Leave them alone>
<Eavesdrop>
“Mon dieu! I grew up in Grenoble, but never found out the truth. What happened?”

“Sorry to bore you with my story.”
“So that’s my tale of woe. In fact, I still keep the original bank note for my materials payment hanging in my office. It’s a reminder to be careful who I do business with.”

“After calling me every name under the sun, she took the dress, but refused to pay the bill. She claimed it was ‘compensation’ for her lost time.” Fatima bites down on the stem of her pipe hard enough that, for a second, you’ll worry that she’ll crack one of her teeth. “I could take her to court, but no judge would take the word of a minor shopkeep over that of an aristocrat. I’d need a good lawyer… which I can’t afford.”
“She hated it. Even went so far as accusing me of ‘butchering’ her design.”

“I finally finished it, and this giant pink confection was a crime against good taste. I hated it so much that I didn’t even write my name in the lining. The Viscountess finally arrived in person to see her creation and…”
“Anytime I suggested that we tone things down for the sake of elegance, she’d threaten to cancel the order, which would leave me holding the bill.”

“Between my other jobs, I spent over a month working on this dress, just getting by on the initial payment for materials. Every other day, I’d get a whole list of changes from her. She wouldn’t even check on the dress in person, but something always had to be bigger or more intricate.”

“Still, starting a new shop is expensive, and the price we agreed on was very nice. He showed me the sketches for this ‘genius’ design and it honestly wasn’t terrible. The dressmaker snorts derisively. “I may be new to running my own shop, but not new enough to fall for that old ruse.”
“This servant swore up and down that making something for this Viscountess was ‘extremely prestigious’, and that I should even work at a discount, for all the new business it would bring me.”

“Well, a month ago, I was approached by a servant working for the Viscountess du Foix, a ‘genius’ who wanted to commission a dress she had designed herself. I quoted a price to this servant and they immediately tried to tell me it was too high.”

The Estates General.asset.1d513277f55a04: In fact, His Majesty has even seen fit to break from tradition to grant the third estate double representation. (Researching Armand is now available to visit on the Paris Map)

Without any illustrations to speak of, you're forced to carefully reread the short passage over and over again. Every tiny statement about the reporter's chosen viewing point of the ceremonies gains a whole new value as you attempt to deduce where Armand was last seen. After checking your findings against your map of Paris, you think you might have a lead.
That's Armand, you're absolutely certain of it!

Clenching the newspaper in your tightening clutches, you reread the article carefully. One of the men described in the article sounds extremely familar.

Long brown hair, young, and tall. Representing the first estate, but has elected to merely wear a fine blue coat for the opening ceremonies. The article writer singled out his casual attire as disrespectful.
In fact it's led to some within the third estate to-
Needless to say, this has made many people extremely unhappy.

Unfortunately, it has come to pass that while they were granted double representation, they haven't been given a doubled amount of votes. The third estate still can only cast as many votes as either the first or the second estate. 

This means that their double representation is purely symbolic.

The third estate, representing over nine tenths of France's population, marched in stern and quiet rows. Dressed in blacks, browns, and other sober colors, they represent everyone from the highest judge, to the wealthiest factory owner, to the lowest peasant.

The second estate, the nobility, strutted down the streets in unison. Bedecked in their finest clothes and jewels, they seemed like an army of swaggering peacocks. Theirs is the realm of tradition, privelege, and loyalty to the Crown.

The first estate, the Church sent clergymen from all over France. Among their number are everything from humble countryside priests in their black cassocks, to resplendent bishops and cardinals bedecked in crimson and gold.

With great fanfare, the Estates General has finally convened. This great meeting is the result of His Majesty, the King, calling together all three estates of France to debate and vote upon how the various crises ravaging the country shall be resolved. 

As part of the opening ceremony, each estate paraded down the streets of the city.

However, the King managed to diffuse this situation with a joke, congratulating the members of the Third Estate on their sudden, and miraculous promotion. He then turned everyone's attention to the business at hand. If this was a subtle challenge to the King's authority on the part of the Third Estate, then it fell flat.
It's not just the Queen either. Many have already seen this incident as an harbinger of more disorder to come.

Whether it was an act of clear rebellion, or mere confusion in the face of ancient and arcane ceremony, many members of the Third Estate put their hats back on. This functionally signalled that they felt themselves the equals of the nobility, and the King.
For reasons that even you find unclear, this whole affair was deemed utterly scandalous. It's said that the Queen herself went pale with rage at this collapse of ceremony.
And so, in Paris, life goes on.

(The Crown has lost a little power)

At a preliminary meeting before the Estates General, the King took off his hat to salute the assembled members. In response, as per custom, all the assembled nobles and commoners removed their hats as a sign of respect. However, after this greeting, only the king and the nobles were supposed to put their hats back on, while the members of the Third Estate were supposed to remain without.

However, after this greeting, only the king and the nobles were supposed to put their hats back on, while the members of the Third Estate were supposed to remain without.
To that end, yesterday revealed one of the strangest of such pitfalls in known memory. This incident centers on who, exactly, is allowed to wear a hat.
The Estates General has led to some interesting quandaries. The King’s made it clear that he plans to set a bold new direction for France, but has been unclear on what that actually means.
The Humane Solution.asset.b3fb09af9fba2b: And so, Paris continues to burn.
Perhaps they shall have to witness this guillotine at work a few more times, before they warm to it.
By all accounts, he was a wicked man. In fact, the crowd that watched his death were unsatisfied with his execution. It was too clean, too quick, too clinical.
In fact, this device has already claimed its first life. A highwayman named Nicolas Jacques Pelletier, who was found guilty of murder, robbery, and rape.
This 'guillotine' kills instantly, for if one is to die, it should be done humanely.

A device that will decaptitate the condemned, quickly and cleanly. No longer will they twist and choke at the end of the hangman's rope. No longer will a missed strike from the executioner's blade leave a screaming man, begging for a second swing.
A physician, named Joseph-Ignace Guillotin, has proposed a device.
