Silently, you part ways when you arrive near your home.
An older drunk, stares at you with a disapproving frown.
With a sigh, you look away, feigning deference until he feels satisfied and walks away with his minor triumph.
You sit up straight, and stare right back at him. You stare as hard as you can, until, with a sneer, he departs. He spits on the sidewalk right before he turns a corner.

After a while, it feels... normal. It feels like how any two people should feel, while in love. Alone together on a moonlit night. 

It feels normal, and that fills you with a special kind of joy.

That word echoes in your mind as your hand brushes the side of Élisabeth's face, tucking a stray lock over hair behind her ear, while she does the same to you. Like a taught thread, the need for discretion attempts to hold you back.
Discretion is for cowards.

To him, and to the rest of the world, you and Élisabeth are just two close friends. Anything closer would be worthy of disapproval, ridicule, even violence. So you hide your feelings, to make society more comfortable. To please the sensibilities of the drunk on the street.
"I hate that we always have to hide, when we're together and well... I figured an empty courtyard might be the next best thing."
"Actually, no. Don't answer that."
The two of you walk together, in heavy silence. While you're sure it couldn't be longer than a few minutes, it feels like it stretches into eternity.
"That's not what I expected, but it makes sense. If she enouraged the King to leave them alone, it could show that the Crown is willing to listen."
"Yvette, is that where your allegiance really lies?"
Eventually, she looks at you with shock and disgust. "The Revolution? You want me to tell my friend to go soft on the people that want to hurt and disempower her family?"
"No more."
"It wasn't. They wanted me to stop talking, so they could control the conversation. I've been giving them what they want."
"The art critics, and those boors in L'Académie, they're the ones who hurt her! I let them blame me, until I blamed myself."
"She told me that it was her favorite. That it was the best painting of her that anyone had ever done."
After a long pause, she speaks again, her voice starting to crack "Do you know what Marie said to me?"
"If I'm to be happy, I must stop letting fools drag my name through the mud."
"Lately, I've been considering some of the things you've said to me. About my critics, and how hard it is to ignore all of their remarks."
"For the first time in a long time, I think I'm really alright."
She glances down at your hands. "Verbally, that is."
With triumphant thoughts of the evening's machinations marching through your head, you go upstairs, already planning what you'll write in your journal before bed.
With sweet thoughts of the evening's details dancing through your head, you go upstairs, already planning what you'll write in your journal before bed.
Burdened with heavy thoughts, you trudge upstairs, already planning what you'll write in your journal before bed.
"I'm sorry to hear that, madame." Camille replies glumly. "If it helps, I've prepared your room, just the way you like it."
"I don't know what that means, but it sounds lovely!" Camille replies, full of enthusiasm. "I've prepared your room, just the way you like it."
"I'm glad to hear that, madame!" Camille chirps, her cheeks flushing slightly. "I've prepared your room, just the way you like it."
"How was your evening?"
At home, Camille opens the door on the first knock. "Bonsoir, Madame!"
The two of you spend some more time together by the fountain, making little jokes and tossing pebbles into the water. It's nice to be together, but eventually you have to part ways.
The sound of a throat clearing snaps you back to reality, and you can feel Elisabeth freeze like a statue in your arms.

An older man staggers by, watching you with the glazed over, uncomprehending expression of a man who's drank beyond his limits. He makes no attempt to hide his staring, and in that moment, your need for discretion feels justified.

The two of you sit close together, at the fountain's edge. You hold hands and watch the moon. She holds onto you with such a tightness, like a sailor thrown overboard, holding onto a rope, trying not to drown.
Despite the risks, your lips meet hers and they are warm. They are soft. Her hand traces up your spine and it feels right. Her fingers entwine themselves in her hair.
"I understand." She says with a smile, tinged with regret.
Discretion.
She flushes, and her voice gets quieter. "I also thought the moonlight was romantic."

You know this place. This is the fountain square where you met when she was still searching for inspiration. This late at night, the square is practically abandoned. The sky is clear and the moon bathes everything in a pale glow. 

"Whenever I've passed through here, this square tended to be empty around now." She explains, gesturing at the open courtyard.

As your mind twists and turns, trying to calculate the political consequences of that little suggestion, you realize that this isn't your normal route home. You must have been too lost in the conversation to notice. 

You glance up and down the deserted and streets and wonder where you're actually going.
"Well, that makes sense. It's good to stick with the people who've supported you in the past, and his Majesty has always been able to count on the Holy Father, the Pope."
"Well, it's hard to argue with that logic. When danger grows close, you generally want the people with guns on your side."
"Well, it would be easy to get Marie to understand their concerns. As an art dealer, my husband is more Bourgeoisie than anything else."
Elisabeth pauses to think about this for a while, tapping her finger against her chin.
Élisabeth pauses to think about this for a while, tapping her finger against her chin. "The Bourgeoisie? Really?"
Elisabeth pauses to think about this for a while, tapping her finger against her chin. "The Military? Really?"
Élisabeth pauses to think about this for a while, tapping her finger against her chin. "The Church? Really?"
"Allies? Like who?"

"Ever since we started talking again, Marie's been asking my opinion on all sorts of things. She feels like the Crown doesn't have many friends left in France, and doesn't know who they should be reaching out to."
She reaches out and loops her arm through your own. The two of you  walk, arm in arm for a while.
The conversation dies down for a minute, while you both recompose your thoughts.
"You're free to think that, if you like, but I've already made up my mind."
She smiles at you. "Please, take the compliment. You don't need to be so modest."
Looking deep into your eyes, she says. "You really have."
"... and well, you've been a big part of that."
"Realizing this, it's made everything better. Even my paintings are coming easier than before. I'm actually excited about my next three patrons."
"These last few weeks, I've been getting better, and one question kept coming back to me."
"To be honest, I think that I was troubled for so long that I forget what being comfortable with myself actually felt like."

"And why not? I have many clients, I'm essentially the personal painter of her Majesty the Queen, and I'm a full member of L'Académie Royale de Peinture et de Sculpture. I'm not even forty years old and I've accomplished more than most will in their entire lives."

"No, it's not that. I've just realized that all my time spent feigning indifference has been a mistake." She pauses to brush away an errant tear. "Indifference isn't working. I need to start defending myself."
"I started talking to Marie again, and she told me that my portrait was her favorite. That it was the best painting of her that anyone had ever done."
"That's the problem. I kept telling myself that letting my detractors say anything they please about me was dignity."
Élisabeth favors you with a big, happy grin. "I knew you'd like that."

A few tears roll down her cheeks, but Élisabeth doesn't seem to notice.

The Last Few Days.asset.2741e9a578f13854: As you consider leaving your house for the first time in weeks, you imagine that the next few days would be a good time to get your affairs in order.
While the violence stretches on, into its own terrifying monotony, you can't help but feel that it's building towards something. Like all of this conflict will finally come to a head.
(You can no longer receive random party invitations)
As you can imagine, this has put a rather serious damper on your social calendar.

In the past, you so much about glory. Glorious uprisings from one group, and the valor in loyalty unto death from the other, but hiding in your house for the last few days, you have yet to see any of that.

There's been fighting in the streets. Roads and alleys are blocked with barricades. The roaring drone of chanted revolutionary slogans merge with orders to disperse, punctuated by screams and gunfire.
The last two weeks have been complete chaos.

You turn to your home find that Camille is already there, holding the door open for you.
“Heaven help you, if you do,” he chuckles, “And please madame, call me Ludovico.”
“Please, call me Ludovico.” He says with a nod before stepping into his carriage and disappearing into the night.
“Hopefully, we’ll meet again under better circumstances.”

The carriage rolls to a stop, cutting him off mid sentence. You hear the crunch of hobnailed boots on cobblestones as the coachman walks to the door, but Father Sidotti opens it first. He steps down and offers you his hand.

“This has been a rare pleasure madame,” he says as you step into the street.
Your mind brimming with new possibilities, you step inside and head upstairs. Slowly, you get undressed and open your journal to record exactly what transpired tonight.
You step inside and head upstairs, your mind still reeling from the day's events. Slowly, you get undressed and open your journal to record exactly what transpired tonight.
“Who was that?” she asks.

“Until we meet again, madame!” He calls cheerily before the carriage drives off into the night. 

You realize that Camille is already waiting for you at the door.

The carriage stops and the coachman opens the door. As you step down into the street, Father Sidotti leans out of the carriage to look at your home. 

“Ah, I see you have chosen to live humbly. It’s good for the soul.” He muses aloud.

The conversation continues apace for the rest of the carriage ride. Most of your free time growing up was spent reading, and ignoring your parents, so you both seem to have a lot in common. When this evening started, you didn’t expect to find yourself in a carriage, discussing Voltaire and Goethe with a Catholic Priest.

Eventually the conversation dies down, the adrenaline rush of the night’s disasters and indignities giving way to simple exhaustion. Father Sidotti settles into his books, and you occupy yourself with watching the scenery go by, and trying not to fall asleep.
“How are you feeling, right now?”
“But what about you? Are you alright?”
A flush of color darkens the young priest’s cheeks. “While I appreciate the offer, please don’t feel obligated to make enemies just for my sake. I might not always be around to save you.”
He shrugs. “Well, at least we’re on equal footing.”
“Would you believe that it’s the first time I’ve shared my carriage with an enchanting woman?”
“Really?” he coughs awkwardly and looks away. “You are too kind, madame.”
“Sorry, I didn’t mean to bore you with my life story. I ramble when I’m nervous.”

“You see, sending a bishop or a cardinal here, with all their retinue, would arouse too much suspicion. It’d make people think something bad was going to happen. A single priest? Nobody notices that.”

“A few months ago, I was pulled aside and told that I would be sent to Paris. There’s been a lot of… unrest here. My superiors in Rome wanted an outside opinion.” He pauses for a moment to fiddle with his rosary.
He blushes for a moment and stares out the window “Though, that made holding mass a little difficult for me. A lot of awkward silences.”

“The seminary wasn’t bad, it was the first time in my life that people were happy that I spent all of my time reading. I was ordained a few years ago and shuffled around to help with various parishes in Rome. All the older priests liked me because I didn’t talk too much.”
“I can certainly understand why.” Father Sidotti replies. He gestures, not at you, but at your situation in general. “I hope, at least, that I’ve managed to make things a little more bearable.”
“Resilience is good…” he replies trailing off for a moment. “Just make sure to give yourself time to rest. Even the most minor of injuries can wear on the soul, if left uncared for.”

“You’re right. I was born and raised in Rome. My family’s about as traditional as it comes, so when my parents had three sons, they knew what to do with us immediately. One man of arms, one man of letters, and one…” he gestures broadly to himself, “man of the cloth.”
“Are you... alright?”

After a few more giggles, his face turns more serious. “I heard that you were searching for your fiance, and that our host thought it would be good sport to ridicule you in front of their friends. Utterly barbaric.” He follows this up by muttering something decidedly unchristian to himself in Italian.
“I’m guessing then that you must be the one I’ve heard about. I’m sorry that our host felt it acceptable to treat you so poorly.”
“While I wasn’t present for it, I heard about what our host put you through. I’m sorry you’ve had to endure such a dreadful humiliation.”
You’re not so sure if you actually feel unflustered, but it’s good that you can project it.

The young priest laughs loudly.

“I must be very fortunate, to have a martyr in my presence. I’m glad to see you made it without any extra holes in you.”
He raises his eyebrows. “What a worrying turn of events. A missing fiance, sudden enemies, and now a missing carriage. It sounds like you’ve been beset by quite the number of misfortunes.”

With a slight smile he exhales, looking less tense than before.

“I’m glad to see that you’re taking this setback in good humor. Not everyone would be so unflustered by such a turn of events.”
“May I ask what happened?”
He stares at you for a while and almost starts talking, before thinking better of it. This process repeats a few more times, before he finally speaks.

The inside of the carriage is very similar to the outside. It’s simple, but lovingly crafted. Father Sidotti sits across from you, his eyes darting between you and the small stack of books on the seat next to him.

He signals the coachman by tapping the ceiling of the carriage, and you head off towards Paris.

A smile flashes across his lips before he glances away.

“‘Ask, and it shall be given you’. I’m sure we can make a stop.” Father Sidotti steps down from the carriage and offers you his hand. He helps you inside.

For the first time today, you see someone look at you with genuine concern. “How terrible! Please, come aboard, it’s no trouble at all.”

He puts down his book and waves you inside.
"How may I help you?"
“Buonasera Castigated Woman. I am Father Sidotti. It’s a pleasure to make your acquaintance.”
“Hello Madame Decaux! Do not worry, I’m sure there’s something I can do for you.”

Behind the door you hear a sputter of barely suppressed laughter.

He opens the door.
“Oh my!” the voice behind the door calls out. After some fumbling, he parts the curtains on the carriage windows.
An accented voice calls out to you. “Uh… who is it?”
You reach out and knock on the door of the carriage. The silhouetted figure jumps in surprise.
"Are you sure, Father Sidotti? I can always make more enemies, if you'd like."
"Thank you, Father Sidotti. Until we meet again."
"A most intriguing young priest. Hopefully someone I'll see again."
"Just a nice man, doing the Lord's work."
"Honestly? I feel terrible, and just hope this day ends as soon as possible."
"I'm not happy with what happened, but I'll be alright."
"Honestly? I feel terrible, and just hope this day ends as soon soon as possible."
"I'm not happy with what happened, but I'll be alright."
"Maybe I'll have to get thrown out of parties more often."
"Don't worry Father, this is new to me, as well."
"Why are you nervous?"
"It's fine, I thought it was interesting."
"Honestly? I feel terrible, and just hope this day ends as soon as possible."
"I'm not happy with what happened, but I'll be alright."
"I get the impression that you're not from Paris. What brings you here?"
"Imagine St. Sebastian, but with insults instead of arrows."
"I'm looking for my missing fiance, but it turns out this party was held by one of his enemies."
"It appears that Parisians have a very different way of entertaining their party guests."
"My carriage is gone, and there's no way I'm walking home in these heels. I need a ride."
"May I trouble you for a ride home? My coachman was tricked into leaving without me."
"It's me, the woman who just got castigated by the host, then thrown out."
"Father, my name is Yvette Decaux, and I am a common woman in need."

You step out of the darkness, suddenly appearing before her dressed in the vision that she imagined for you.

You step back inside for a few minutes, and while his help isn't as quick as Camille's, or as sensual as Madame Gazel's, you still find yourself dressed and looking as amazing as ever.

Looking around, expecting some sort of specter or sorcery at play, you instead notice Madame Gazel's servant, René. You're especially surprised to notice that he's no longer wearing his black armband.
His eyes widen as you produce the black satin oufit that Madame Gazel gave you, so long ago. René smiles, broadly and genuinely.
As René walks away, you head inside to Madame Gazel. She is reading by a lantern amongst the flowers. A single spot of sumptuous darkness, in a halo of light.
He smiles his same thin smile, but his eyes have more emotion in them than before.
He bows, and begins to dismiss himself.

You arrive in the gardens, which are filled with a combination of blooming roses and lillies. The scent is almost overwhelming. René indicates to Madame Gazel, who is waiting on a chaise longue at the center of the garden. A table is set up next to her, draped in a black sheet. She hasn't noticed you.

No tour of the house is provided, but you do stroll through the dining room and the salon towards the garden in the back. You're offered a glass of wine from an impressively dusty bottle, which you take. It's simply nice to be prepared.
With a thin smile, the ever silent René waves you in, and leads you beyond the gate and into the house.
You go to knock on the gate, but it opens before you can touch it.
It's like someone modeled the building on her.

Of course, even if you didn't know the address already, you'd certainly be able to recognize the place. An elaborate, fashionable rococo building sits back from the street and behind a gate. The windows are shrouded by gauzy black curtains.

Hastily walking to Madame Gazel's home with your hood up, you realize that you've never actually been there before. Thankfully, you've already memorized her address from all the letters she's sent you.

The Morning, After Disaster.asset.8c284f: No. You must not go back. You cannot go back. Not while a single candle of your ambition still burns.

However, stronger than that exhaustion is the simmering rage you feel. At the outrageousness of your circumstances, at the injustice of your treatment, and at the thought of going back to you tiny village, after finally making it here to Paris.

You feel exhausted. Not physically, but in your very soul. Like your fate in Paris has already been decided, and that to remain here would be pointless. It would just be the humiliations of last night... over and over again.
(You have lost a little peril)
(You have gained a little credibility)
(La Trompette du Peuple is now available to visit in the Paris map)
With that, your day begins.

Nothing is going to make last night go away. 

The only option is deciding what to do next.
With that, your day begins.
“They’d have to get their stories from somewhere, why not you? In fact, I bet you’d be great at that, Madame!”

Camille taps her chin thoughtfully. "Well… when I was at les Halles the other day, someone mentioned something about a newspaper with these amazing society pages. I think it was called 'La Trompette du Peuple'."
Maybe someone would be willing to buy this gossip. Is that a thing people do?

You take a few moments to finish your drink in silence and collect your thoughts. Something that keeps coming to mind is all the gossip you’ve heard during your time at the party. Most of it was idle prattle, but some of it felt scandalous and valuable. Without an inheritance or a job, you’ll need a way to make some money.

You drink the wine slowly, taking in the aroma between sips. Armand was always the sort to keep a few, particularly nice bottles on hand to impress important guests. The wine smooths the edges off of last night’s memories, and you feel a little more ready to face the dangers of this new world that you’ve entered.
A few minutes later, Camille returns with a decanter of red wine and the least chipped wine glass in the house. “Por vous, Madame.” She pronounces, before serving you.

Camille returns so quickly with the tea that you’re certain she made it ahead of time. It’s piping hot, fragrant, and not too bitter. You drink the brew in silence, the gears of your mind slowly getting up to speed. The tiredness fades. Your anger does not.
"What can I get you Madame?”
“Still, I can’t let you start your morning without something to drink. It wouldn’t be healthy! What can I get you Madame?”
“Now, if you wanted me to clean up after a murder... That, I could do!”
“While you wait, I must insist on getting you something to drink. Going without wouldn’t be healthy!"
“Certainly Madame! What can I get you?” Camille asks with a smile.
“Unfortunately Madame, the only things I’ve killed are rats, fish, chickens, and one porcupine. Those didn’t look very accidental either. I don’t think I’ll be able to help with a murder.”
“I’m sorry Madame, the other cushions are waiting to be washed. We can’t have you end your life with a dirty pillow. It would be improper, for a woman of your station.”
“It looks like you had quite an active night. Is there anything I can get you?”
Camille pops into your room, already dressed and ready for the day. “Bonjour, Madame!” she beams.

You awaken the next morning, in a bed that still feels unfamiliar. In the process of waking up, you start to recall the last nights humiliations, and wish that they were merely the product of your fitful dreams. Unable to go back to sleep, you spend some time tossing and turning in bed before finally sitting up.
"I've gone from Baroness-to-be, to gossip monger. Great. Just great."
"Merci, Camille. I think I'll do just that."
"I'll have some wine. Numbing the memory of last night will make me less anxious."
"I'll have some wine. Numbing the memory of last night will make me less anxious."
"I'll have some wine. Numbing the memory of last night will make me less anxious."
"Tea, please. I'll need to keep my wits about me if I'm to regain people's trust."
"Tea, please. I'll need to keep my wits about me if I'm to regain people's trust."
"Tea, please. I'll need to keep my wits about me if I'm to regain people's trust."
*Sigh* “Some kind of refreshment, please.”
“I’m not sure… do you know how to make a murder look like an accident?”
“Please find a spare pillow and smother me.”
The National Assembly.asset.2a06e3d982ce: This is, of course, in direct conflict with the orders of the King, who determined the voting system used in the Estates General. The nobility in the first estate have called on the Crown to issue a swift and decisive condemnation of this rebelious act.
And so, in Paris, life goes on.

However, His Majesty, King Louis XVI has yet to issue any official statement on the National Assembly. Reports suggest that he has instead chosen to spend the last few days in long meetings with the courtiers of his privy council, trying to reach a decision.

Enraged by their unfair representation, representatives of the third estate have created their own body called 'The National Assembly', and invited members of the other estates to join them in negotiations on what would, in theory, be fairer ground.
For the last few weeks, discussions at the Estates General have been dragging out and growing ever more divisive.
The Perils of Journalism.asset.af4d46a4b: Once you're certain he's not going to be ambushed, you head back to your own home, with Hansel in tow. It's a rough world out there, but that's exactly why you hired a bodyguard.
You and Hansel escort Pierre back to his office, mostly to make sure the journalist's new enemy doesn't try to finish the job he started.
(You have gained 15 Livres)
He shuffles through his pockets, and hands you a handful of coins as a 'bonus' for your help.
"The dangers we risk for exposing the truth, non?" Pierre asks with a massive smile. "I'm sure he would have torn me to ribbons, had you not intervened."
With a string of curses, the enraged man storms off, unsatisfied. Dusting off his worn coat, Pierre rejoins the conversation.
(You have gained some credibility)
Pierre laughs. "Don't worry monsieur! It's a surprise to me as well!"
The man leans around Hansel to yell at you indignantly. "Are you serious? You're really going to defend this Pierre, of all people?"
"Hurf... that could have gone better, non?" Pierre asks through a forced smile. "I'm sure I would be in far worse condition, had you not intervened."
(You have gained some peril)
The assailant glares at you before he departs. "If you're associated with this wretch, I would advise that you watch yourself."
Suddenly, he turns on his heel and swiftly punches Pierre in the gut. The journalist doubles over in pain.
The fire of his ire dying, the enraged man starts to walk away. "He's all yours."
(You have lost some credibility)
Absolutely beside himself, the man growls. "I have half the right mind to thrash the both of you, but I will be merciful for now. "
Pierre's smile quickly melts away, as does your ruse.
The assailant walks away, disappearing into the crowd.
(You have gained some credibility)
"... now that I've acquired my own satisfaction" He gestures generously to Pierre, who is bent double in the road. "He's all yours, madame."
Suddenly, he turns on his heel and swiftly punches Pierre in the gut. The journalist doubles over in pain.
"Non, non..." The man replies, shaking his head in disbelief. "This scum looks far too happy to see you. You're one of his compatriots aren't you?"
"Well, I am a gentleman, and I will let you have your satisfaction." He says, starting to walk away.
Once you're certain that he's not going to die of his injuries, you head back to your own place. It's a rough world out there.
You help Pierre back to his office, which is also where he lives...
(You have gained 7 Livres)
He shuffles through his pockets and hands you a few coins as a 'bonus' for your help.
(You have gained some peril)
The assailant glares at you before he departs. "If you're associated with this wretch, I would advise that you watch yourself."
(You have gained some credibility)
"Hurf... the indignities we suffer for exposing the truth, non?" Pierre asks through a forced smile. "I'm sure I would be in far worse condition, had you not intervened."
Suddenly, he turns on his heel and swiftly punches Pierre in the gut. The journalist doubles over in pain.
Take aback by this situation, and the fire of his ire dying, the enraged man starts to walk away. "He's all yours."
Pierre shrugs and grins. "If it's any consolation, this is all a surprise to me as well."
He sneers at you. "Honestly, I just can't believe there's anyone left in Paris who would willingly defend this man."
Roughly pushing Pierre aside, Hansel steps close and looms over the enraged stranger. "Anything you do to that man, I will do to you, only a lot harder."
The man looks at you, aghast. "Madame, are you absolutely serious?"
"What?" The man says, noticing you for the first time. "This scoundrel has wronged you as well?"
Now, this is a problem. If Pierre gets thrashed to death, there'll be nobody left to buy your gossip!
The man grabs Pierre by the shirt collar and drags the diminutive journalist closer. "How about I knock some sense into you? Will you remember then?"
Pierre laughs nervously. "Monsieur, I'm afraid you're going to have to be a little more specific as to your identity..."
"How dare you? You salacious cur! You've aired my private matters for all the world to see and I've been nearly ruined!"

As you grow less distant, you realize exactly what's familiar. It's a certain overpowering cologne. There's only one man in Paris who's snorted so much snuff as to think such a vile concoction was a good idea. In fact, someone is screaming at him, right now!
Travelling about town you find yourself, once more, in a fountain square. You're not sure if you've been to this particular one before, but something feels distantly familiar.
"Hansel, I need Pierre in one piece. Handle this." <Requires Hansel>
"Step away from Pierre, or there will be hell to pay!"
"Monsieur, you can't kill him! Not before I get my chance to hurt him..."
The Price of Loyalty.asset.3e52cd8d28dfc:
(The Crown has lost a little power)
(The Military has gained some power)
(The Military has moved towards the Crown by a decent amount)
And so, in Paris, life goes on.

(The Crown has lost some power)
(The Military has moved towards the Revolution by a decent amount)

Yesterday, the worst outcome came to pass. Every soldier and sailor has seen their pay 'delayed', with no indication of when it'll appear next. Needless to say, a lot of well armed people are quite unhappy, and this does not make the Crown look good.

Much to everyone's surprise though, the Crown managed to reach deep into its purse to make sure their debts to their soldiers and sailors were properly settled. This may have exacerbated their financial issues elsewhere, but it's earned them loyalty for now. It's also helped the Military appear stable and reliable.

However, the financial situation of the Crown is perilous right now, and no small amount of people are worried. You've heard of cases all over the city where taverns are already refusing to issue soldiers lines of credit, for fear of never getting paid back.
The military's payday was yesterday, something that should be an absolutley normal event. In fact, anywhere else, it would be.
The Price of Treason.asset.f07256529ff10: Whoever this man is, you can't help but feel some pity for him. You've heard grumbling on the streets that judges are becoming more heavy handed with their charges and sentencing. That they're hoping to keep order by making an example of a few criminals.
If you hurry, you might be able to visit him one last time, but you only have three days before the worst occurs.
(This is Goodbye is now available to visit on the Paris Map)

You frantically search through the article for any clue as to where he's being held. It appears that he's being kept in a Guet Royal watch station in the middle of the city, near the square where they'll soon decapitate him.
You still hadn't managed to find him, and now your first solid lead is learning of his upcoming execution? How the devil could this be? You still have no idea what had really happened to him!
You'd only just managed to find Armand, and now he's going to be executed? How did he get caught? Did one of the Hapsburgians sell him out? What happened?

Your blood runs cold as you read these words over and over. 

How? How would this have happened?
'The now disgraced Baron Armand de Marbo will be executed via beheading, in three days time, for high treason and conspiracy against His Majesty King Louis XVI.'
You almost skip the article, until you spot a name... no... it can't be...

The front page story is mostly concerned with a man who's been sentenced to death for treason. Apparently he was the member of some nefarious organization conspiring against the King, and their leader is still at large.
Sitting at your vanity in the morning, you read the newspaper while eating a light breakfast that Camille prepared for you.
The Promised Painting.asset.21afe0f43046: “Oui madame!” Camille cheerily replies, and places a variety of different hors d'oeuvres on your desk. You nibble at the morsels, and spend the rest of the evening contentedly examining your position, and your plans yet to come.
“Oui madame!” Camille cheerily replies, and pours you a glass of ruby red wine. You sip your wine, and spend the remainder of the evening plotting the culmination of your vengeance.
“Oui madame!” Camille cheerily replies, and begins pouring you a cup of hot tea. You sip your tea, and spend the remainder of the evening calmly planning your next move.
“Would you like any of this, madame?”
“Oh, well then.” Camille looks down and the mostly untouched refreshments. “I shall simply have to have everything prepared for guests sooner.”
With that, Marguerite takes a second snack from the tray, then leaves.
Marguerite turns to you. Her eyes look tired and hopeful. “Thank you for doing this. I know this isn’t all just to benefit me, but I still appreciate what you’re doing.”
“She left, and I need to leave too.” Marguerite replies, taking one snack from the tray, then another. “I’m opening shift at the Cafe tomorrow.”
“Huh? Where did Madame Le Brun go?” Camille asks, looking about the room in confusion.
Marguerite clears her throat, “Can we talk about something else?”
“So, to answer your question: I don’t know.”
“I was too afraid of what he could do, if he ever wanted to.”

“But still, whenever he wanted something.” She pauses to fidget with her skirt, looking at the ground. “I could never forget the difference between us. That he had so much. So much power over every aspect of my life. I never said ‘no’ to him, but sometimes I wanted to. I was just too afraid to do it.”
“You never got to see it but, when he wants to, Maximin can be sweet. He can be witty, thoughtful, and charming, and all those other things you can want a man to be.”
“Not really, not always,” she says slowly.
“I guess I like it.”

“I don’t know much about paintings, but I think this is a great one. If this painting means that Maximin can’t threaten me anymore, then I like it.” She sighs and keeps staring at the painting for a while.
“Am I supposed to like it? I mean, it’s terrifying.”
“Would anyone like tea or wine?” Camille asks, entering the room with a variety of refreshments and snacks on a tray.
“I might even be able to get a full night’s sleep. That would be nice.”
When she hears this question, her eyes stop focusing on you. Instead they focus on some distant point in space, far away from everything.
“Do I like it?”
“I can’t wait. I can’t wait to be able to live my life in peace. To not have to look over my shoulder whenever I leave the cafe.”
“It’s just so strange, to see how I feel, up in a great big painting,” she whispers.
(You have an invitation to Maximin's Grand Salon)

She walks down the stairs and you hear her let herself out.

Marguerite is still staring at the painting, her face a mixture of awe and horror.
“Now I’m actually going to leave.” Élisabeth explains before going to the door.

As you look down at the invitation, you can feel a wicked grin form on your lips.

This is it. This is where you can destroy Maximin, in front of all his sycophants.

“It looks like Maximin’s holding a salon in a few days, showing off a bunch of new paintings from artists he sponsors. I know that he only invited me so he could brag about their ‘revolutionary’ work and all of their ‘extremely deep meanings’. I think you might have a better time than I will.”
At the last second she turns back. “Oh, I almost forgot your surprise!” She rifles through her pockets and pulls out a letter sealed in deep red wax. The seal has already been broken.
“Me? Of course you will!” She replies, turning towards the door.
“De rien,” she replies, turning towards the door.
“My work here is done then!” Élisabeth says, gathering up the sheet.
“It’s how I feel.” Marguerite says, her voice trailing off. She looks simply stunned. “It’s how I feel whenever I think about him.”
“It’s-” Élisabeth starts before Marguerite cuts her off.
You see fear.
Looking back at Marguerite and Gabriel in the painting, you don’t see the calm and serious expression of a dutiful family.

Here, Maximin is off to the side of the family, separated by some distance. His darkly colored coat blends with the shadows. This, matched with his grim expression and looming stance, makes him feel like a predator waiting to strike.
Not in this one.
In most family portraits, the father is usually at the center of the scene, or in some position to show him as a protector or leader.
“I actually painted that poisonous creature from memory. I hope he likes it.” Élisabeth adds proudly.
The biggest change however, is that Élisabeth added Maximin himself to the painting.

Marguerite, dressed in the uniform of a maid sits with Gabriel on her knee, looking every bit the dutiful mother. Gabriel is dressed in soberly colored but expensive clothes, befitting the status of his inheritance. His resemblance to Maximin is absolutely uncanny.
It’s not hard to see what she means. You asked for a simple portrait of Marguerite and her son Gabriel, but Élisabeth created an entire family scene.
“I took a few creative liberties with the original request, but I think it was worth it.” Élisabeth says, admiring her own work as if she was seeing it for the first time.
It. Is. Perfect.
The room is silent while everyone takes it in.
“Almost there, don’t worry.” Élisabeth says, gripping the edges of the sheet.
“Can we just… get this over with?”
“Behold!” Élisabeth calls out, pulling off the sheet covering the portrait in a single movement.
“Don’t worry, all the fun will be over in just a few moments...” Élisabeth replies, gripping the edges of the sheet.
“When all your ‘romance and mystery’ could endanger me and my son, I get to be a spoilsport.” Marguerite states flatly.
“Why would I want to ruin the surprise? Can’t you allow just a little bit of mystery in your life?” Élisabeth asks while adjusting the sheet that’s covering the painting.
“Especially because someone here hasn’t even let me see the painting yet.” Marguerite continues, glaring at Élisabeth.
“Oh, great.” Marguerite replies with forced enthusiasm. “More waiting to see if my life is going to be ruined.”
“Well, that’s good to hear…” Marguerite says with some relief.
“So, this is it? The big unveiling?” She asks nervously.

As Camille exits the room, she’s quickly replaced by Marguerite, who seems to be doing her best to appear calm and collected. While it’s good that she agreed to the portrait being painted, you can tell that this whole affair still makes her deeply uncomfortable.

“It’s so good to have guests in the house again!” Camille exclaims with barely contained glee. 
“I’ll go fetch everyone some refreshments.” 

She curtseys to you both, before heading to the door.

A few moments later, the door opens and Camille enters with Élisabeth, both working together to carry the portrait, which has been covered with a sheet. They prop it up against the fireplace.

You didn’t expect it to be this big, it’s practically as tall as you are!
There’s a knock at the door. “I’ll get it, madame!” Camille calls cheerily from downstairs.
That evening, with the house prepared for guests, you wait for Élisabeth to arrive with the portrait.
“I’ll have whatever it is that Marguerite seemed to take so much of.”
“A glass of wine would be nice.”
“Some tea please, Camille.”
“Did Maximin… did he force himself upon you?”
“Do you like it?”
“Soon everyone will know the truth about him.”
“Will I see you again soon?”
“Merci beau coups, Élisabeth.”
“Non, my dear. This is just the dress rehearsal.”
“Oui, this is it.”
The Question of Cuisine.asset.a04894a628: Eventually, you manage to excuse yourself in order to investigate the rest of the party, and see if there's anything else you can do before it ends.

You divert yourself, chatting with the gourmand about France's culinary heritage. Unfortunately she's still drunk on her recent victory, and spends too much time lecturing you to be an agreeable conversational partner.
Desserts. Your priorities lie with desserts. Is that a crime?

He leaves, and it appears that yes. It is a crime.

Truly the world is bereft of justice.
(You have lost a little favor with Ludovico)
(You have lost a little favor with Ludovico)
Ludovico turns to you, shocked and hurt. "Ah, yes. I see where your priorities lie."

Ludovico turns to you, shocked and hurt. "Ah, yes. I see where your loyalties lie."

Face etched with imperious disgust, she storms away from the both you. Judging from the way the crowd is looking at you, you're pretty sure that you couldn't have committed a more vile sin unless you swore allegiance to the devil himself.
Well, you certainly didn't expect this to become so heated.
"Madame, you dare? You dare denigrate the culinary traditions of your own mother country?"
"Just because one starts something, doesn't make you them the master of it. Italy may have started some of our fine traditions, but we're the ones that finished them."

(You have lost a decent amount of credibility)
(You have gained a little peril)
"Well that's fine." The woman says proudly. "They're fine desserts."
A pall falls across the room. It's only then that you realize that your conversation had a larger audience than you first realized. we are.
"Exactly!" The woman happily replies.
"It is a simple question. Whose chefs have contributed more to cuisine.  Those of France, or Italy?"
Ludovico sees you and perks up. "Madamme Decaux! Would you be able to help us with something?"
Ludovico sees you and perks up. "Yvette! Please come here, I need your help with something."
"Father, forgive them, for they know not what they do..." Ludovico mumbles to himself while rubbing his temples.
"I beg your pardon? This dish has only been created in France. Thus it is a French recipe." She replies, enunciating every syllable very carefully.

"While I'll admit that, this fine Far Breton is certainly a recipe from Brittany, I must remind you that both cakes and custards only came to France because Catherine de Medici brought her Italian chefs with her when she married your Henri II all those years ago."
"That's a very interesting choice of words." He replies, and you swear that his Italian accent has grown more pronounced.
Ludovico slowly puts down his fork.

"I'm so glad you like it! It's a Far Breton. My chef is from Brittany, and the dish is a specialty of his. He's a true French chef to his very heart, which makes him one of the finest in the world." The guest replies with a great deal of pride.
"Oh my, this cake is spectacular! The custard inside compliments the fruits just perfectly."

You spot that priest, Father Sidotti, sampling some of the desserts and talking with another guest. He looks like he'll have something interesting to discuss, and the sweets look quite enticing as well. With your mind made up, you decide to approach them.
"Pardonne-moi, I'm merely here to sample some desserts. Please don't mind me."
"Italian techniques are the foundations of modern French cuisine. Theirs is better by default."
"I'm sorry Ludovico, but my loyalty is to France."
The Revolution.asset.9a5309caca3c23845b7: The king met with the crowd and even had food delivered to them from the royal stores, but after months of famine, they were no longer satisfied with a simple meal.
Monarchist elements of the nobility have been angered and alienated by this move, but their influence of the course of the country dwindles every week.
And so, Paris continues to burn.

Paranoia and desertion have withered the revolutionary ranks, as the Crown recently released an edict of mercy, promising legal clemency to any revolutionary that throws down their arms. This edict excludes all that have been branded as 'revolutionary leaders'.

This sudden violence began a string of defeats that the Revolution is still reeling from. The Crown has the stability and the necessary alliances to supress any threats to their power as soon as they arise, preventing them from gaining momentum.

When their demands went unanswered, the mob attempted to storm the palace to present their demands to the royal family. In response, the guards opened fire, dispersing the crowd with force. Revolutionaries have come to refer to this tragic event as 'The Women's Massacre'.
Scores of young nobles have pledged their lives to the cause of liberty, and willingly cast aside their own privileges in the name of reforming the nation. It is a heady time, indeed.
Now more recently, this revolutionary fervor has reached the highest levels of nobility, with the abolition of all noble titles, orders, and other symbols of the ancien regime.

Late in the night, they stormed the palace, killed what guards they found, and captured the royal family. This angry mob escorted the royal family back to Paris, growing more agitated by the minute. Only the gallant intervention of the Marquis de Lafayette prevented further violence.

Last year, thousands of angry women marched from Paris, mostly armed with homemade pikes, to beseige the Palace at Versailles. The Crown, lacking power and useful allies, had a skeleton crew of guards left to defend themselves.

Last year a large crowd of women marched upon Versailles to demand bread, mostly armed with homemade pikes. However, this crowd was disjointed and sporadic, with many deserting upon seeing the armed guards at the palace.
While your own progress has ground to a halt, it feels like the advancement of time around you has only sped up.

“I think this conversation would best be continued somewhere more discreet.” The other woman intimates to her companion.
“Oh, I’m sorry, did we interrupt something?” One of them asks, arching a single eyebrow imposingly.

You listen to them go back and forth for a little while, and you hungrily soak up all the details to this story that you can. Eventually, you realize that you’ve been admiring this vase for a suspicious amount of time.

“I’m not so sure, a handmaiden told me that the Queen privately vowed not to leave her son’s side until he slept through the night, but she’s been with him for over a week. He keeps waking up in fits of coughing.”

Vows. Specific details. Lives in the balance. Now that’s what makes good gossip!
Guiding her friend gently by the elbow, they disappear off into a different corner of the party, judging you all the way.

The other woman suddenly steps in between the two of you and cuts off her companion. “I’m sorry, but this is a private matter. I’m glad your brother is doing well, please give him our regards.” Her smile is cold, and her posture stiff.
Eventually, you part ways with each other, so you can explore the rest of the party.

You continue to chat with them as they dance around the issue of who, exactly, you’re talking about. You helpfully offer up some home remedies for coughing fits that you’ve heard in the past, and they act as grateful as ettiquette requires.
“Well, our… friend’s son has been sick for quite some time now, and-” one woman starts cautiously.

“Well, our… friend’s son has been sick for quite some time now, and she’s been taking it quite hard. I recently heard that she privately vowed not to leave her son’s side until he slept through the night, but she’s been with him for over a week. He keeps waking up in fits of coughing.”

You decide against engaging them in conversation, or listening in. While it’s nice to have some reliable gossip, you don’t need it that badly right now. Instead, you spend some time wandering about the party, sipping at your wine, taking in the sights and the sounds.

You sip your wine and pretend to be admiring a nearby vase, while keeping your ears perked up and focused on the womens’ conversation.

They don’t seem to suspect a thing.
Your brother never actually came down with the illness, but he’s not here to contest that fact. You smile and pretend to be oblivious as to who they’re discussing, so as to mask your intent.
“He’s overcome the condition before, perhaps he’ll do it again?”

Your ears perk up at this. The Queen’s eldest son is only seven years old, but he’s been afflicted with consumption for years now. Rumors don’t have much value, but if there’s some evidence to this claim, then this could be valuable Gossip indeed.

“It’s been days since the Queen has made any official appearances at Versailles.” One the women fiercely whispers to the other. “It is said that the Dauphin’s health is worsening, and she spends every minute by his side.”
You approach a pair of women who are already in the midst of conversation, speaking quickly in low voices. They don’t seem to have noticed you.
<Leave them alone>
<Eavesdrop>
“Pardonnez moi, but I heard you mention consumption, my brother suffered from it too.”

The two of them hurry away to another part of the party. While that certainly didn’t make you any friends, you know that Madame Le Brun is a far more important person to be on the good side of, than two random hangers-on at a party.
“We should go.” The woman interrupts, taking her friend gently by the elbow and leading him away.

Finally, the man manages to say, “Ah, I see that Madame Le Brun has quite the fan. I must concede that there are few portrait painters who have so superbly captured the image of the Queen, God preserve her. I suppose that-”
After a period of awkward silence, the guests depart to explore the rest of the party. As they leave, you watch them whisper to each other and glance back at you, pointedly.
"She's alright because she makes pretty pictures? What an insightful defense!” the woman replies with such fluid sarcasm that you almost mistake it for a genuine compliment.
With an exchange of polite nods, you part ways with these guests in order to explore the rest of the party.

Slowly they nod, and their faces break into polite smiles. “My, my, I didn’t realize we had such a fan in our midst. I suppose one can forgive an artist for being so eccentric, as long as their work remains beautiful.”

That qualifier at the end of her statement feels unnecessary, but it’s an improvement.
The once snide guests stand quiet for a while, considering your point.
“Haha, yes, I think we’ll all see that soon enough.” The woman titters, trying to laugh behind her hand.
Your surprising forwardness leaves the room quiet for a few moments. The man and the woman both glance back and forth between each other for a while, trying to figure out what to say.
Surprised, the man turns to you with a cocked eyebrow. "Oh? You really think making beautiful work can justify her transgressions?"
The woman turns and asks you furtively “Ah! What do you think of Madame Le Brun and her… eccentricities?”

“I have no idea.” the woman replies, glancing furtively around the room. “Ever since Madame Le Brun started painting portraits of the Queen herself, she seems to feel that’s she’s above normal social niceties. It must have cost a fortune just to make an opening in Madame Le Brun’s schedule.”

“Do you have any idea how Marcelle managed to get this?” A man asks, his face the picture of shock, not taking his eyes off the painting for a moment. He must know the Viscountess de Foix very well in order to use her first name so freely.

“Nobody is above the consequences of society, not even great painters. Le Brun will have hers yet.”
“I think Madame Le Brun can be as rude as she pleases. Her skills speak for themselves.”

You turn your back on the painter and start to disrobe, one article at a time. It's slow, but confident. After all, if you had anything to hide, you wouldn't be here, doing this.

The conversation trails off and you spend the next hour simply posing and watching Élisabeth paint. She seems more relaxed, as if a weight has been lifted from her mind.
"Thanks Yvette! I'll send out letters to some of the business leaders in Paris tomorrow."
"Thanks Yvette! I'll send out letters to some of the military officers in Paris tomorrow."
"Thanks Yvette! I'll send out letters to the bishops in Paris tomorrow."
"That feels sensible." She admits, already considering the idea. "What I need right now is clients, and I'd rather have ones that can pay well than ones that can't."

"You really think so?" She asks, already considering the idea. "I guess they would, and none of my commisioned work is truly immodest, so perhaps they'll actually appreciate my paintings."

Ghoulishly, for a moment you wonder if the Viscount Alfonso du Foix killed le Vassor and took their money, but that wouldn’t make sense. You can’t just kill and rob someone of thousands of Livres without someone noticing. Too noticeable.

Besides, what kind of thief would pay to bury their victim?

(A Pauper's Grave is now available to visit on the Paris Map)

‘November 12th, 1768 - Reinterment Expenses, Cimetière du Calvaire’.
In thirty years, the Viscount made no attempt to pay back his loans to de Vassor. In fact, the first thing he bought with his newfound money was…

Marcelle’s father was landless, dead broke, under a mountain of debt, and had been for years. He only got by loans from someone named ‘Gatien de Vassor’, who was also a client at this bank. Then, overnight, the Viscount had a respectable sum of money, and everything just started working for him.
You’re looking deep into the past now, at entries that are over thirty years old. Suddenly, everything just stops making sense…

Not long after that, you get to when Marcelle’s father, Alfonso du Foix was the account holder. It appears that he was the one who made the family’s money, not Marcelle. 

While that would make for a good jab at a party, it’s not enough. A member of the aristocracy having a fortune they didn’t earn is more normal than not.

Flipping through the pages, you eventually find some entries for Marcelle’s account. She certainly appears to have the fortune one would imagine from a woman of her station, but still you press on. 

From the looks of it, the rumors that Marcelle spent a fortune on her father’s funeral were well founded. It must have been a truly lavish affair.

Years ago, your father’s eyes started to have trouble focusing on small letters, so you had to help him with the accounting. Now it appears that all those late nights spent in his office, squinting at barely legible expenses, are about to pay off.

“Hopefully, we shall meet again under better circumstances. Bonne nuit, Yvette.” She says to you before closing the carriage door. With a crack of his whip overhead, René, the coachman spurs the horses into action, and the carriage winds through the streets and disappears into the night.

With a rustle of skirts, Honorade leans to the carriage door and opens it for you. As you’re helping yourself down into the streets, Honorade peers out at your shabby home and simply shrugs to you.

“Don't worry. Everyone has to start somewhere.”
The lurching stop of the carriage jolts you awake. You notice a wet patch of drool on the corner of your mouth, which you furiously blot away with a handkerchief.
Soon, you find yourself struggling just to stay awake. Every blink feels like it lasts an hour.

The journey to your home in Paris lasts for a long time, but it doesn’t feel that way. Honorade plays the part of hostess wonderfully, always managing to guide the conversation in a satisfying direction. Unlike so many other of the persons you’ve met in Paris, she seems completely uninterested in polite small talk, focusing instead on more interesting subjects.
As the journey drags on, the conversation slows down. The darkness, and rocking of the carriage, combined with the exhaustion of the night’s events slow you to a crawl.
“I’m glad to know you haven’t fallen into that little trap, yourself.”
“We yearn for a beloved that would do anything for us, and us for them. Yet, the moment we see a pair of lovers actually behaving this way, we tell them that they’re sick or wicked.”
“Life is for the living, but feeling is a part of living, even when the emotion is upsetting.”
“However...” Honorade gestures to the luxurious gloom about her. “I feel that the trappings suit me, non?"

Her knowing, devilish demeanor cracks for a moment, and her eyes take on a far-away, melancholy look to them. “That… is exactly how he would have put it. You are both right. One can’t grieve forever, there is so much of life left to live.”
Until now.
“I think so too,” Honorade replies, her lips twisting up into a devilish smile. “How can we say that we love someone, if we’re not willing to defy the rules of decency to do it?”

“I can’t say that I agree, or at least I don’t think that mourning’s set length is there for a good reason. I think those rules were set up by those who can’t stand to see others in pain, so they simply demanded that everyone buries how they feel.”
Despite her mournful trappings, you haven’t yet seen Honorade look particularly forlorn.
“What do you think? Is two and a half years too long to mourn for lost love?”
“You’re very polite. Most, when they hear that, take it upon themselves to chide me for my ‘breach of decency’.”

You maintain a neutral expression, but you can’t help but dwell on the fact that two and a half years is far longer than any prescribed period of mourning. You’ve heard of widows wearing a black weeper on their gowns for a few months longer than most, but this is something else entirely.
“You see, as of last week... it’s been two and a half years.”
She sighs. “That is a reasonable question, though not one I like answering.”
“That’s really sweet, and I’m not just making fun. You are a sweet woman.”
“Then again, you wouldn’t be the first.”
She’s not wrong.
“Perhaps I am getting ahead of myself, but I imagine the next question you’ll ask me is how long I have been in mourning for, no?”
“You’re ruled by your passions. Such things aren’t in vogue in this ‘Age of Reason’, but I feel like if one is going to be controlled by anything, it should be love.”

She may only be a few years older than you, but the way Honorade smiles at your answer is almost nostalgic. “Running away to the beauty of Paris? To see and be seen among the philosophers and the persons of fashion?”
“It must have been quite an awful, stifling place to make you run half way across the country to be here.”
“You left everything behind and travelled far away, all for love?” Honorade smiles distantly and runs her hand along the satin cushion that she’s sitting on. “I like that.”
“What made you want to come to Paris?”
“Hah! Listen to me. That was certainly more than you asked for. Now, what about you?”

“However, when Charles passed, I kept getting invitations. He had so many friends, and I hated the idea of letting him down more than the idea of being in a room filled with people I don’t care about, so I started going.”
“Crowds don’t really suit me, you see. I prefer more… intimate gatherings.”

“Until a few years ago, I was actually quite the homebody. My husband’s textile mills made more than enough money for me to live a life of leisure, which he was happy to let me do. Though, I’m sure he was frustrated by my unwillingness to attend all the big parties his clients would throw.”
“I’m glad to know you haven’t fallen into that little trap, yourself.”
“We yearn for a beloved that would do anything for us, and us for them. Yet, the moment we see a pair of lovers actually behaving this way, we tell them that they’re sick or wicked.”
“Life is for the living, but feeling is a part of living, even when the emotion is upsetting.”

“To answer your question, which I’ve so rudely stated for you: I don’t. Not really, at least.” She chuckles into her glass before taking a leisurely sip. “Of course, now that I know what they did to you, I have no intention of getting to know that conniving wretch at all.”
She’s not wrong.
“Forgive me for being rude, but I imagine your next question is that you’re wondering how I know our host.”

You maintain a neutral expression, but you can’t help but dwell on the fact that two and a half years is far longer than any prescribed period of mourning. You’ve heard of widows wearing a black weeper on their gowns for a few months longer than most, but this is something else entirely.
“You see, as of last week... it’s been two and a half years.”

“Would you believe that I don’t? Not really, at least.” She chuckles into her glass before taking a leisurely sip. “Of course, now that I know what they did to you, I have no intention of getting to know that conniving wretch at all.”
She sighs. “That is a reasonable question, though not one I like answering.”
“Please, indulge me. What would you like to know?”
Honorade interrupts your train of thought “But of course, the best way to fix that, is by not being strangers. Ask me some questions, so you may properly judge my character.”
You are slightly uncomfortable, probably because she’s making a good point. You stop to wonder if you’d be any good at leaping from a moving carriage.
“I know I would be…”
She examines you intently while she sips her water. “I assume you are already planning your revenge, non?”
“You must be quite strong, to endure such dreadful treatment.”
“How vile,” she replies. “To find a person who has been beset by such great misfortune, then to mistreat them so, just to posture among one’s cohorts? That is truly despicable.”

After a long silence, Honorade leans over to the window and looks out through one of the few spots not obscured by black crepe.

“Now, I’m sure you already know just how dangerous it is to accept rides home from strangers. We could be going anywhere right now, and you wouldn’t even know it.”

“If you insist…” Honorade replies, looking off to the side while she sips at her water. “However, at the risk of being intrusive, I must caution against carrying all of your burdens alone. It is not healthy.”
Honorade doesn’t speak for a while, instead choosing to stare into her glass of water with an expression of surprise and disgust.
“Why were they so dreadfully cruel to you?”

“While I saw you a few times during the party tonight, and I know that you’re new to Paris, we never had a chance to properly introduce ourselves. However, I did manage to hear about your most unfortunate run in with our host.”
She knocks delicately on the roof compartment, and with a clean crack of the coachman’s whip, the carriage makes way towards Paris.
“Just Yvette it is, then.” She replies with a shrug. “Shall we be off?”
“It’s a pleasure to meet you, Yvette Decaux. Shall we be off?”
“My name is Honorade, what should I call you? Madame…”
A delicate, pale hand reaches out from the darkness to you. You take her hand and step inside.

With that, René, the coachman hops down from his box and opens the door for you. He wears the same, colorful livery of most servants, but it’s adorned with a black badge on his breast. You squint to peer at the woman inside, but to no avail. Between the swags of black crepe obscuring the windows, and the lack of lanterns within the carriage, the entire inside is shrouded in gloom.
“René, the door please.”

After a few seconds, your eyes adjust to the shadows and you see the woman in front of you. She’s older than yourself, but still younger than you’d expect. Dressed in luxurious mourning clothes, she reclines easily in her seat, clutching a fine glass filled with water.
You hear some rustling from inside the carriage, and she opens the door for you. You help yourself into the carriage.
“How tragic,” replies the voice with a trace of amusement. “What kind of person would I be, if I didn’t take pity on such a helpless soul?”
“Certainly, I should be able to help with that.” The voice replies.
“What seems to be troubling you, madame?” calls out a voice from inside the carriage.

Should you knock on the door? Call out? You’ve heard that courtiers in Versailles grow out one of their fingernails, so they can scratch on the door, as it’s considered less disruptive. Locked in this cycle of indecision, you curse the fact that you cut your nails this morning.

The coachman pays you no heed as you approach the sumptuously decorated carriage. Normally, you find yourself to be quite fearless in social situations, but something about this whole scenario gives you pause.
"I don't think I'm comfortable with seeing you that way, Honorade."
"Yes, I do. Madame Gazel."
"Why, exactly?"
“A very… intriguing woman. One that I’m hoping to see more of.”
“A wealthy widow with a fondness for helping strangers. She's kind, in her own way."
“I’m sorry, I don’t feel comfortable with that.”
“Yes, Madame Gazel.”
“And what would that be?”
“Certainly.”
“A very… intriguing woman. One that I’m hoping to see more of.”
“A wealthy widow with a fondness for helping strangers, she seems nice.”
“There’s something romantic about casting aside decency, for the sake of grief.”
“Mourning has a set length for a reason. Life is for the living.”
“One should take as long as they like, but they can’t do it forever.”
“I’d always dreamed of being in Paris, it’s a city at the center of the world.”
“I was sick of my life in the country, I wanted to get away.”
“I came here because I’ll do anything for love.”
“I’d always dreamed of being in Paris, it’s a city at the center of the world.”
“I was sick of my life in the country, I wanted to get away.”
“I came here because I’ll do anything for love.”
“There’s something romantic about casting aside decency, for the sake of grief.”
“Mourning has a set length for a reason. Life is for the living.”
“One should take as long as they like, but they can’t do it forever.”
“How did you know our host?”
“How long have you been in mourning?”
“Please, don’t worry about it, I’ll be fine.”
“Apparently, they’re enemies with my lost fiance, and wanted to snub him by berating me.”
“Just Yvette, s'il vous plaît.”
“Decaux. Yvette Decaux.”
“Madame, my fiance is lost, our host denounced me, and my carriage is gone. Can you help?”
“May I bother you for a ride home? My carriage left without me.”

Well, it sounded a lot better in your head than it did out loud.

You spend a few more minutes with these guests, exchanging banter and political ruminations. Eventually, with an exchange of polite nods, you part ways with your erstwhile friends in order to explore the rest of the party.

Mulling over your point, he nods affably, but his friend is the one to speak first. “You’re saying that the more unflinching and dire Saint-Just becomes, the more reasonable we seem. Maybe we should encourage him.”
He doubtfully cocks his eyebrows, and you can feel your point start to slip away. “Then, once we won, we'd just… convince the violent uprising to stop.”

After your toast, you spend a few more minutes with these guests, exchanging banter and political ruminations. Much of it is unfamiliar to you, but by the end of the conversation you find yourself able to keep up pretty easily.
“Agreed! To a new, harmonious France!” His friend raises her wineglass and you toast together, and drink deep of the red wine you obtained from a servant earlier.
She stalks away from you as well, leaving you with your thoughts. You take a few moments to collect yourself before rejoining the rest of the party.
“I hope you’re happy.” His friend hisses to you, surprisingly angry. “That kind of talk doesn’t benefit anyone.”

“It’s that zealous part that I’m worried about.” The older man replies, furrowing his brow. “I’ve never met him, but I know a few men that have. Saint-Just is very open to the idea of violence in order to secure freedoms for the Third Estate, and is quite cold to those who don’t agree. One isn’t supposed to treat politics like a religion.”

“Quite right!” The man agrees with you. “The Estates General is soon, and we need to stay focused on what’s important, and what we can all agree on. Taxing the nobility, engaging in land reform, and beginning a constitutional monarchy.”

“Ah, I see… you are one of his ilk.” The older man replies to you, taking a sip from his wine glass. “Another who can’t imagine progress without violence. I’m sure Saint-Just will love your fervor, give him my regards.”

Nodding along, the older nationalist replies. "So, you saying that if we let Saint-Just to form his own movement, we'd give the first and second estates an easy choice. They must either negotiate with our peaceful reforms, or fight Saint-Just's uprising."
The woman grimaces. “I hadn’t heard that part. What about you? Do you think it was right to invite Saint-Just?”

“I’m not. I’ll concede that Saint-Just’s a charismatic boy, that much is true. However, don’t forget that he led a student revolution at his own university. A wry smile creeps across the woman’s face and she pats her friend reassuringly on the arm “A maniac? Surely, you’re just exaggerating.”
Before you can answer, her friend interrupts you “Of course she is. That maniac is the only person anyone here is talking about.”

“Louis Antoine de Saint-Just” the older man whispers to you as he steps to the side and lets you into the conversation circle. “Our host, Maximin, invited him from Blérancourt. Maximin thinks the young man would make a fine revolutionary, but I have my doubts.”

The woman stares are her friend incredulously “How, exactly, does one spot ‘a penchant for extreme violence’?”

“Is he even attending tonight?

You spot two guests who are talking to each other, but appear to be on the lookout for someone else. Every few moments their conversation breaks off so they can collectively glance around the room. Something about them feels tense.

"He's not an enemy. His willingness for violence lends your rhetoric weight."

This is Goodbye.asset.0eeaedd33634abc498: You walk home at a brisk pace, but in your mind your already at work. You're planning, calculating.
You walk home, and try to determine your next steps. You must not let yourself come to the same end.

Eventually, you pick yourself up and wander home, lost in a daze. You try to make sense of everything, and simply fail. 

Still, it's up to you to decide what happens next. You owe him that much.
You shut your eyes and take a deep breath to gather your thoughts, and steady your nerves. You cannot allow yourself to panic. Not now, when so much is at stake.

You look back at the watch post, shake your head and tut disapprovingly. One story ends, but yours must continue. 

You'll be sure of that.

Your nose and eyes sting terribly, as tears come forth to cloud your vision. Before you even realize what's happening, you'd sobbing in the middle fo the street. 

It just feels so unfair.
It takes a concerted effort to decide exactly how you feel about what's transpired.

Suddenly thrust back into the sunlight, you shield your eyes from the glare and stare at the world. You stare at the people going about their daily lives, completely unaffected by everything you've just learned.

"I researched the name a little on my own, and to my knowledge it appears that the von Holbeins are an Austrian noble family. Specifically, they're one in deep decline. It might explain why she started the Frankish Hapsburgian Society, as she might hope that it could reverse her family's fortunes."
"I don't know how you can use it, but knowing Johanna's real identity has to be the key in preventing her from finishing whatever designs she may have upon you."

"This society I joined is led by a woman named Johanna du Jardin. I met her for the first time when I moved to Paris, and quickly became her closest confidant as we worked to accomplish this hidden agenda."
Slowly, he calms. "Her Majesty the Queen, is already of Austrian birth. It felt like a natural fit to try to connect us to Austria, the house of Hapsburg, and the Holy Roman Empire."

His voice rises in energy and anger. "The aristrocacy refuses to change! The revolutionaries want to tear everything down, but can't agree on what they'll build up in its place, which is a recipe for violence and disaster. Our only hope is to subborn France to a forward thinking empire with the resources to solve our problems."

He stares at the heavens and sighs. "I was blind to it, but during our time working together on this secret project, Johanna had come to desire me romantically. I never felt the same way, and she became embittered. Recently, she must have reported me to the authorities as an act of revenge."

"Back in our village, a bookseller named Charles reached out and invited me to secretly join the 'Frankish Hapsburgian Society'. We saw that France's problems had become too large for the monarchy alone to solve."
Before you can say anything else, he ushers you out of the watch post, and into the street, before returning to his duties.
With a grunt, the guard enters the cell, and wordlesslly motions for you to leave.

He steps towards you, and you step back in turn. He reaches for you, but as the guard opens the door, he lets his hands drop to his sides. Now, even Armand realizes that you have grown beyond him. "Au revoir, Yvette."

You leap towards him and he envelops you in his arms. It's a quick kiss, but one done with the hope of lasting forever. One that hopes to delay the inevitable. 

You're interrupted by the sound of the door opening.
He breathes deep and forces a smile. "I guess this is goodbye."
You start at the sound of a sudden, knocking on the cell door. "Your time is up, madame!"
He suddenly stops, steps back and just watches you, as if seeing you for the first time. "I'm sorry, but I just wanted to take a moment to remember this. You're actually here... mon dieu."

"I tell you this because I'm worried that she might not be satisfied with my execution. She is an unbelieveably driven woman, Yvette, and I think you may be the next target of her vengeance. If that occurs, you should be prepared."

You think about Johanna's signet ring, which you found in the house, hidden beneath the floorboards. The mysterious sigil on it is likely her family's crest. She herself said that she wanted Armand to have it because that it would be enough to convince people to help Armand cross the border. That means her family must be relatively well known.

"Regardless, I believed in the righteousness of our cause, so I didn't remark on it to her. Still, it's likely what has kept her so focused. Her family's return to prominence relies on the success of the Frankish Hapsburgian Society."

He steps close to you and continues in a low voice. "Johanna du Jardin's real name is Johanna von Holbein. I saw it in a document she accidentally left out once. She doesn't yet know that I've learned this about her."
"Johanna du Jardin, the woman who reported me to the Guet Royal, is not what she appears to be."
He shakes his head violently, in an attempt to focus. "Yvette, none of that matters now. What does matter is that you're in danger."

"Yvette? Ma chérie?" He croaks, his voice tired and strained.
This is the man who you came to Paris for, all those months ago. It feels like it's been a lifetime.
The guard lets you into the cell, before locking the door behind you. Inside you find Armand. He has a few bruises on him, and his complexion is wan and unhealthy.
"Do not abuse my patience, madame." He snarls at you while he fumbles with his keys to the cell.
"Good." He replies, before unlocking the cell door.

Not here. It's as silent as a cemetary. If you strain your ears, you can just make out the creaking of wood as prisoners watch you through the gratings in their cell doors, but nobody says a word as you're lead to Armand's cell.

Inside, the holding cells are quiet, dank, and abominably dismal. You'd read of prisons being raucous places, perpetually alive with the din of prisoners banging their cups against the bars, and howling their innocence to anyone who would hear them.
"This way, Madame." He replies, waving for another watchman to take his post while he leads you inside.

He cocks a single eyebrow, while you hold up your hand to show your engagement ring as you say this. He stares at you in silence for a few moments, as if this might let him divine your true intentions. You prove inscrutable to him, so eventually he stops.

You hold up your hand with your engagement ring as you say this, and he eyes you hard, as if by staring at your hard enough he could ascertain some measure of criminality from you. Eventually he stops.
"What is your business here, madame?" He asks, his voice flat and monotone.

This however, feels different. Château de Vincennes was a place for holding low risk prisoners like petty theives, and printmakers who angered the Crown. This watch station's cells are a place for brigands and murderers, and Armand is charged with high treason.
You approach a guard, who eyes you suspiciously, and barely moves from his post at the door.
Your heartbeat rising, you wonder if there's some way you could smuggle Armand out, some scheme that would allow you to spirit him away, like Antoine asked you to do at Château de Vincennes.
He will die by the executioner's sword, as is tradition.

Rounding a corner, you see the watch post, and the squat building feels massive and imposing. In an open square nearby, you can see the wooden frame of the gallows, but that's for common criminals. 

Armand is a nobleman.
You were always certain that you'd be able to find Armand, eventually. You just never expected it to be like this.
Walking to the watch post, you expected to feel a swirl of emotions, but you mostly just feel numb.
"Johanna von Holbein? It looks like I have some work to do..."
"What a shame Armand, what a shame, indeed."
"Au revoir, Armand... I'll miss you."
"Yes... I guess it is."
